In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the effects of dietary fiber on the gut microbiota and host health, focusing on the types, sources, and structures of dietary fiber, the metabolic pathways and enzymes involved in fiber fermentation, the factors influencing fiber intake and digestion, and the potential mechanisms underlying the fiber-host interaction. We also discuss the challenges and future directions for studying the effects of dietary fiber on the gut microbiota and host health. Citation: Zhang L, Wang Y, Xiayu X, Shi C, Chen W, Song N, et al. (2020) Dietary fiber intake, gut microbiota, and host health. Crit Rev Food Sci Nutr.
output: - The interaction between dietary fiber and the gut microbiota: Implications for host health and research directions

input: The development of vaccines against SARS-CoV-2, the causative agent of COVID-19, has been a remarkable scientific achievement. However, the emergence and spread of viral variants with mutations in the spike protein, which mediates viral entry into host cells, poses a challenge for the efficacy and durability of the current vaccines. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the impact of spike mutations on the antigenicity and immunogenicity of SARS-CoV-2, and discuss the implications for vaccine design and deployment. We highlight the need for continuous surveillance and evaluation of viral evolution and vaccine-induced immunity, as well as the development of broadly protective and easily adaptable vaccine platforms. We also emphasize the importance of global collaboration and equitable distribution of vaccines to prevent the ongoing transmission and diversification of SARS-CoV-2.
output: - The impact of spike protein diversity on SARS-CoV-2 vaccines: surveillance, evaluation and adaptation

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance and mood of healthy older adults. Sixty participants (aged 60-84 years) were randomly assigned to one of four conditions: classical music, jazz music, white noise, or silence. They performed a battery of cognitive tests, including memory, attention, and executive function tasks, and completed a mood questionnaire before and after the intervention. The results showed that classical music enhanced memory and mood, compared to the other conditions. Jazz music also improved mood, but not memory. White noise and silence had no significant effects on either outcome. These findings suggest that listening to classical music can be a simple and effective way to enhance the cognitive and emotional well-being of older adults.
output: - The influence of music type on cognitive performance and mood of older adults

input: The development of vaccines against COVID-19 has been a global priority since the emergence of the novel coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 in late 2019. Several vaccine candidates have entered clinical trials and some have shown promising results in terms of safety and efficacy. However, there are still many challenges and uncertainties in the vaccine development process, such as the durability of immune responses, the protection against viral variants, the scalability of production and distribution, and the ethical and regulatory issues. In this review, we provide an overview of the current status and progress of COVID-19 vaccine research, focusing on the different types of vaccine platforms, the preclinical and clinical data, and the potential advantages and limitations of each approach. We also discuss the future perspectives and challenges for COVID-19 vaccine development and deployment.
output: - COVID-19 vaccine development: a critical appraisal of the current status and prospects

input: The development of artificial intelligence (AI) systems that can perform complex tasks across different domains has been a long-standing goal of AI research. However, most existing AI systems are designed for specific and narrow applications, and lack the ability to generalize and transfer their knowledge to new domains or tasks. Meta-learning, or learning to learn, is a promising paradigm to address this challenge, as it aims to enable AI systems to learn from a variety of tasks and adapt to new ones with minimal data and effort. In this survey, we provide a comprehensive and structured overview of the recent advances and challenges in meta-learning, covering a wide range of topics such as meta-learning algorithms, meta-learning applications, meta-learning benchmarks, and meta-learning theory. We also discuss some of the open problems and future directions for meta-learning research.
output: - Meta-Learning for Generalizable and Adaptable Artificial Intelligence: A Structured Overview and Perspective

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance and mood of older adults. Sixty healthy participants aged 60 to 83 years were randomly assigned to one of four music conditions: classical, jazz, pop, or silence. They completed a battery of cognitive tests measuring memory, attention, and executive functions, as well as a self-report measure of mood. The results showed that classical music enhanced memory and mood, compared to the other music genres and silence. Jazz music also improved memory performance, but only for verbal material. Pop music and silence had no significant effects on cognition or mood. These findings suggest that music can be a potential cognitive enhancer for older adults, depending on the type and the domain of music. The possible mechanisms underlying the music-cognition relationship are discussed.
output: - Music genre differences in cognitive and mood outcomes for older adults

input: Background: The emergence and spread of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a global health threat that undermines the effective treatment of bacterial infections and increases the risk of morbidity and mortality. Livestock-associated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (LA-MRSA) is a type of AMR bacteria that can be transmitted from animals to humans through direct contact or via the food chain or the environment. The prevalence and dynamics of LA-MRSA in pig farms and pig farmers are poorly understood in many countries, including China, which is the largest pig producer in the world. Methods: We conducted a longitudinal study to investigate the prevalence, persistence, and molecular characteristics of LA-MRSA in 20 pig farms and 10 pig farmers in Sichuan province, China. Nasal swabs were collected from pigs and farmers at three time points over a period of 6 months and screened for MRSA. MRSA isolates were characterized by spa typing, multilocus sequence typing, and antimicrobial susceptibility testing. Results: The overall prevalence of LA-MRSA in pigs was 24.5% (147/600), and the prevalence increased significantly from the nursery (10.0%) to the fattening (30.7%) stage. Sixteen out of 20 pig farms (80.0%) had at least one LA-MRSA positive pig, and 11 farms (55.0%) remained positive throughout the study period. The overall prevalence of LA-MRSA in pig farmers was 8.0% (8/100), and four farmers (40.0%) were persistent carriers of LA-MRSA. All LA-MRSA isolates belonged to clonal complex 9 (CC9) and t899 was the most common spa type (92.6%). LA-MRSA isolates showed high resistance rates to tetracycline (99.3%), erythromycin (89.3%), and clindamycin (87.3%), and low resistance rates to gentamicin (3.3%), sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim (2.0%), and ciprofloxacin (1.3%). No resistance to vancomycin, teicoplanin, linezolid, or daptomycin was detected. Conclusion: Our study revealed a high and increasing prevalence of LA-MRSA CC9 in pigs and a low but persistent prevalence of LA-MRSA CC9 in pig farmers in Sichuan province, China. These findings highlight the need for enhanced surveillance and intervention strategies to prevent and control the spread of LA-MRSA in the pig industry and the potential transmission to humans.
output: - Prevalence, persistence, and molecular characterization of LA-MRSA CC9 in pigs and pig farmers: a 6-month longitudinal study in Sichuan, China

input: The development of effective vaccines against SARS-CoV-2, the causative agent of COVID-19, is a global priority. Several vaccine candidates are currently undergoing clinical trials, but the immunological correlates of protection and the durability of the immune response are still unclear. In this review, we discuss the current knowledge on the humoral and cellular immune responses elicited by SARS-CoV-2 infection and vaccination, and the challenges and opportunities for vaccine design and evaluation. We highlight the importance of neutralizing antibodies, antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity, and T cell-mediated immunity for preventing and controlling SARS-CoV-2 infection. We also examine the factors that may influence the magnitude and quality of the immune response, such as viral variants, pre-existing immunity, age, and co-morbidities. Furthermore, we provide an overview of the different types of vaccines against SARS-CoV-2, their advantages and disadvantages, and their immunogenicity and efficacy in animal models and human trials. Finally, we outline the future directions and open questions for SARS-CoV-2 vaccine research and development.
output: - Humoral and cellular immunity to SARS-CoV-2 infection and vaccination: a review

input: This paper presents a novel approach to automatically generate captions for images based on deep neural networks. We propose a hybrid model that combines a convolutional neural network (CNN) for image feature extraction and a recurrent neural network (RNN) for natural language generation. The CNN encodes the input image into a fixed-length vector, which is then fed into the RNN to generate a caption word by word. The RNN is trained with a maximum likelihood criterion, as well as a reinforcement learning objective that directly optimizes a metric of caption quality, such as CIDEr. We also introduce a new dataset of image-caption pairs, collected from Flickr, that is larger and more diverse than the existing datasets. We evaluate our model on several benchmark datasets, and show that it achieves state-of-the-art results on both image captioning and image retrieval tasks. https://doi.
output: Image captioning and retrieval with deep neural networks and reinforcement learning

input: Background: The COVID-19 pandemic has posed unprecedented challenges to the health care systems worldwide. Rapid and accurate diagnosis of COVID-19 infection is crucial for timely and effective management of patients and prevention of disease transmission. However, the performance of the current diagnostic tests, such as reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and chest computed tomography (CT), is limited by various factors, such as availability, cost, sensitivity, specificity, and turnaround time. Therefore, there is an urgent need for developing alternative or complementary diagnostic methods for COVID-19. Methods: In this review, we summarize the current knowledge and recent advances on the potential role of artificial intelligence (AI) in the diagnosis of COVID-19. We searched PubMed, Google Scholar, and preprint servers for relevant studies published until December 31, 2020. We included studies that used AI techniques, such as machine learning and deep learning, to analyze various types of data, such as clinical, laboratory, imaging, and genomic data, for COVID-19 diagnosis. We also discussed the challenges and future directions of AI applications in this field. Results: We identified 97 studies that met our inclusion criteria. The majority of the studies focused on the use of AI for chest imaging analysis, such as segmentation, classification, and quantification of lung lesions. Some studies also explored the use of AI for clinical decision support, such as prediction of diagnosis, severity, and prognosis of COVID-19 based on clinical and laboratory data. A few studies investigated the use of AI for genomic analysis, such as identification of viral origin, evolution, and mutation. The studies reported promising results of AI techniques, such as high accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and efficiency, in COVID-19 diagnosis. However, the studies also had several limitations, such as small sample size, lack of validation, and heterogeneity of data sources and quality. Conclusion: AI has the potential to be a valuable tool for COVID-19 diagnosis, especially when integrated with other diagnostic methods and clinical information. However, more rigorous and robust studies are needed to validate and optimize the performance of AI techniques and to address the ethical, legal, and social implications of AI use in health care.
output: - Current and Future Applications of Artificial Intelligence in COVID-19 Diagnosis: A Critical Review of Literature

input:
The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance of older adults. Sixty healthy participants aged 60-75 years were randomly assigned to one of four groups: classical music, rock music, white noise, or silence. They performed a battery of cognitive tasks, including memory, attention, executive function, and mood, before and after listening to the assigned auditory stimulus for 15 minutes. The results showed that classical music improved memory and mood, while rock music impaired memory and mood. White noise and silence had no significant effects on any cognitive measure. The findings suggest that music can modulate cognitive functioning in older adults, depending on the type and characteristics of the music. * Music is a universal form of human expression that can evoke various emotions and influence cognitive processes [1, 2] . Previous studies have shown that music can enhance cognitive performance in young adults, such as memory, attention, and executive function [3, 4, 5] . However, the effects of music on cognitive functioning in older adults are less clear and more inconsistent [6, 7, 8] . Some studies have reported positive effects of music on memory, attention, and mood in older adults [9, 10, 11] , while others have found no effects or even negative effects of music on cognitive performance [12, 13, 14] . These discrepancies may be due to the differences in the types and characteristics of the music used, such as tempo, rhythm, melody, and genre [15, 16, 17] . Therefore, it is important to investigate how different types of music affect the cognitive performance of older adults.

Input: The influence of music genre on cognitive performance and mood in older adults
output: - Cognitive and mood benefits of classical music versus rock music in older adults: A 15-minute intervention study

input: The human microbiome, the collection of microbes that live in and on the human body, is a key player in health and disease. The microbiome influences various aspects of human physiology, such as metabolism, immunity, and behavior. However, the mechanisms by which the microbiome exerts its effects are not well understood. One of the challenges in studying the microbiome is the complexity and diversity of the microbial communities, which vary across different body sites and individuals. To overcome this challenge, researchers have developed various methods to manipulate the microbiome, such as antibiotics, probiotics, prebiotics, fecal microbiota transplantation, and engineered microbes. These methods allow for the alteration of the microbiome composition and function, and the investigation of the causal relationships between the microbiome and the host. In this review, we summarize the current state of the art of microbiome manipulation methods, their applications in basic and translational research, and their limitations and challenges. We also discuss the ethical and social implications of manipulating the human microbiome, and provide some perspectives for the future of this emerging field.
output: - The art and science of human microbiome manipulation: a critical review of methods and outcomes

input: The development of novel anticancer agents is an urgent need for clinical oncology. Among the different strategies, targeting the tumor microenvironment (TME) has emerged as a promising approach to overcome drug resistance and improve therapeutic outcomes. The TME is composed of various cellular and non-cellular components, such as fibroblasts, immune cells, blood vessels, extracellular matrix, and signaling molecules, that interact with cancer cells and influence their behavior. In this review, we focus on the role of exosomes, which are nanosized vesicles secreted by various cell types, in the TME. Exosomes can mediate intercellular communication and modulate various aspects of the TME, such as angiogenesis, immune response, metastasis, and drug resistance. We summarize the current knowledge on the biogenesis, composition, and functions of exosomes, and discuss their potential as biomarkers, therapeutic targets, and drug delivery vehicles for cancer treatment. We also highlight the challenges and opportunities for the clinical translation of exosome-based therapies.
output: - How exosomes shape the tumor microenvironment and affect cancer outcomes

input: In this study, we investigated the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance and mood of healthy older adults. We randomly assigned 60 participants to one of four conditions: classical music, jazz music, white noise, or silence. They completed a battery of neuropsychological tests and mood scales before and after a 20-minute exposure to their assigned auditory stimulus. The results showed that classical music improved both memory and attention, while jazz music enhanced verbal fluency and mood. White noise had no effect on cognition or mood, and silence had a negative impact on memory and mood. We suggest that music can be used as a non-pharmacological intervention to enhance cognitive functioning and well-being in older adults.
output: - The effects of music, white noise, and silence on neuropsychological outcomes and mood in older adults

input: The development of artificial neural networks (ANNs) has enabled various applications in computer vision, natural language processing, speech recognition, and other domains. However, the design and optimization of ANNs often require extensive human expertise and trial-and-error, which limits the scalability and efficiency of the process. To address this challenge, neural architecture search (NAS) has emerged as a promising technique that automates the discovery of optimal or near-optimal network architectures for a given task. NAS methods typically explore a large and discrete search space of possible architectures, and use different strategies to evaluate and select the most promising candidates. In this survey, we provide a comprehensive and up-to-date overview of the main concepts, techniques, and challenges of NAS. We categorize the existing NAS methods according to their search space, search strategy, and performance estimation strategy, and discuss the trade-offs and limitations of each category. We also highlight some of the recent trends and directions for future research in NAS, such as multi-objective optimization, network pruning, transfer learning, and meta-learning.
output: - A Survey on Neural Architecture Search: From Search Space to Meta-Learning

input: The gut microbiota is a complex and dynamic community of microorganisms that influences host physiology and health. Dysbiosis of the gut microbiota has been associated with various diseases, such as inflammatory bowel disease, obesity, diabetes, and cancer. However, the mechanisms by which the gut microbiota modulates host metabolism and immunity are not fully understood. One potential mediator is the production of metabolites by the gut microbiota, which can affect host cells and tissues through various pathways. Among these metabolites, short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) are the most abundant and have diverse biological functions. SCFAs can act as energy sources, signaling molecules, epigenetic modifiers, and modulators of the immune system. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the biosynthesis, transport, and sensing of SCFAs, and their effects on host metabolism and immunity. We also discuss the potential applications of SCFAs as therapeutics for various diseases.
output: - Biosynthesis, transport, sensing, and effects of short-chain fatty acids in the gut microbiota-host axis

input: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of different concentrations of sodium hypochlorite (NaOCl) and chlorhexidine (CHX) on the bond strength of fiber posts to root dentin. Sixty single-rooted human teeth were endodontically treated and divided into four groups according to the irrigant used during post space preparation: 1% NaOCl, 2.5% NaOCl, 5.25% NaOCl, or 2% CHX. Fiber posts were luted with a self-adhesive resin cement and sectioned into four slices. The push-out bond strength was measured using a universal testing machine. The failure modes were observed under a stereomicroscope and classified as adhesive, cohesive, or mixed. Data were analyzed using ANOVA and Tukey's test. The results showed that the bond strength values were significantly affected by the irrigant type (p < 0.05). The 5.25% NaOCl group had the lowest bond strength, followed by the 2.5% NaOCl and 2% CHX groups. The 1% NaOCl group had the highest bond strength among all groups. The predominant failure mode was adhesive for all groups. The conclusion was that the concentration of NaOCl influenced the bond strength of fiber posts to root dentin, and that 1% NaOCl was the most favorable irrigant for this purpose.
output: - Comparison of sodium hypochlorite and chlorhexidine as root canal irrigants for fiber post luting

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance and mood of healthy older adults. Sixty participants aged 60 to 75 years were randomly assigned to one of four conditions: classical music, jazz music, pop music, or silence. They completed a battery of cognitive tests measuring attention, memory, and executive functions, as well as a mood questionnaire, before and after listening to music or silence for 15 minutes. The results showed that classical music improved spatial working memory and verbal fluency, jazz music enhanced verbal memory and mental flexibility, pop music increased processing speed and mood, and silence had no significant effect on any measure. These findings suggest that music can be used as a cognitive enhancer for older adults, depending on the type of music and the cognitive domain of interest.
output: - Music genre and cognitive domain specificity: a study of music listening effects on older adults' cognition and mood

input: The gut microbiota is a complex and dynamic community of microorganisms that influences host physiology and health. Diet is one of the major factors that modulates the composition and function of the gut microbiota, and dietary interventions have been proposed as a tool to manipulate the microbiome for therapeutic purposes. However, the inter-individual variability in the response to diet is a major challenge for developing personalized nutrition strategies. In this review, we discuss the sources and consequences of this variability, and the potential role of factors such as baseline microbiota, host genetics, age, and health status in modulating the effects of diet on the gut microbiota. We also highlight the need for longitudinal, large-scale, and well-designed studies that can capture the complexity and diversity of the diet-microbiota-host interactions.
output: - Personalized nutrition and the gut microbiota: understanding the variability in dietary responses and outcomes

input: The development of effective vaccines against COVID-19 has been a remarkable scientific achievement, but the global distribution of these vaccines remains highly unequal and insufficient to achieve herd immunity. In this paper, we analyze the ethical and practical challenges of allocating COVID-19 vaccines among and within countries, and propose some principles and strategies to address them. We argue that vaccine allocation should be guided by the goals of minimizing the global burden of disease, protecting health systems and essential workers, reducing the risk of new variants, and promoting global justice and solidarity. We also discuss the criteria and mechanisms for fair and efficient distribution of vaccines at the national level, taking into account the epidemiological, social, and economic factors that affect the vulnerability and needs of different groups. We conclude that a successful vaccination campaign against COVID-19 requires not only scientific and logistical coordination, but also ethical and political commitment to the common good.
output: - Minimizing harm and maximizing justice in COVID-19 vaccine distribution: a framework for ethical and practical decision-making

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance of older adults. Sixty healthy older adults (mean age = 68.5 years) were randomly assigned to one of three groups: classical music, rock music, or silence. They performed a battery of cognitive tasks, including memory, attention, and executive function tests, while listening to the assigned music or no music. The results showed that classical music enhanced memory and attention performance, while rock music impaired executive function performance. Silence had no significant effect on any cognitive domain. The findings suggest that music can modulate cognitive processes in older adults, depending on the type and characteristics of the music. This study provides empirical evidence for the potential use of music as a cognitive enhancer or distractor for older adults.
output: - Cognitive effects of classical, rock, and silent conditions in older adults

input: The human brain is a complex and dynamic system that enables various cognitive, affective, and motor functions. Studying the brain's structure and function is essential for understanding human behavior and health, as well as developing interventions for neurological and psychiatric disorders. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a powerful and versatile tool for non-invasively probing the brain at multiple levels, from macroscopic anatomy to microscopic tissue properties, and from static connectivity to dynamic activity. However, MRI data are often noisy, incomplete, and indirect, posing significant challenges for extracting meaningful and reliable information about the brain. Machine learning, a branch of artificial intelligence that involves creating algorithms that can learn from data, offers a promising framework for addressing these challenges and advancing the field of neuroimaging. This review provides an overview of the main applications, methods, and challenges of machine learning for MRI-based brain research, with a focus on four domains: segmentation, registration, decoding, and prediction. We also discuss the potential ethical and social implications of using machine learning for brain imaging, and provide some guidelines and recommendations for future research.
output: - Advancing brain imaging with machine learning: a comprehensive overview

input: The development of efficient and selective catalysts for the electrochemical reduction of carbon dioxide (CO2) to value-added chemicals is a major challenge in the field of renewable energy conversion. Among various metal-based catalysts, copper (Cu) exhibits unique properties that enable the production of hydrocarbons and oxygenates at relatively low overpotentials. However, the performance of Cu catalysts is limited by their low selectivity and stability, as well as their high demand of energy input. To address these issues, different strategies have been employed to modify the physicochemical properties of Cu catalysts, such as tuning the morphology, size, composition, defect, and interaction with supports or additives. In this review, we summarize the recent advances in the design and synthesis of Cu-based nanomaterials for CO2 electroreduction, with a focus on the correlation between their structural features and catalytic performance. We also discuss the possible mechanisms and reaction pathways involved in the CO2 electroreduction process on Cu-based catalysts, as well as the challenges and perspectives for future research in this emerging field.
output: - Tailoring the properties of Cu-based nanomaterials for enhanced CO2 electroreduction activity and selectivity

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance of older adults. Sixty healthy participants aged 60-75 years were randomly assigned to one of four conditions: classical music, jazz music, white noise, or silence. They performed a battery of cognitive tasks, including memory, attention, executive function, and mood, before and after listening to the assigned auditory stimulus for 15 minutes. The results showed that classical music improved memory and mood, while jazz music enhanced attention and executive function. White noise had a detrimental effect on memory and mood, while silence had no significant effect on any cognitive measure. These findings suggest that music can modulate cognitive processes in older adults, depending on the genre and the task. The possible mechanisms and implications of these effects are discussed. Citation: Lee J, Park S, Kim J, Choi Y (2020) The Effects of Music on Cognitive Performance in Older Adults: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis. PLoS ONE 15(12): e0243768.
output: - Music as a Cognitive Modulator in Older Adults: The Role of Genre and Task

input: The human brain is a complex and dynamic system that enables various cognitive, affective, and behavioral functions. Studying the brain's structure and function is essential for understanding the neural basis of these functions, as well as the mechanisms of brain disorders. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a powerful and versatile tool for non-invasively probing the brain's anatomy, physiology, and activity. However, MRI data are often noisy, incomplete, and high-dimensional, posing significant challenges for analysis and interpretation. Machine learning is a branch of artificial intelligence that aims to discover patterns and extract knowledge from data using computational models and algorithms. Machine learning techniques have been increasingly applied to MRI data to address various problems, such as segmentation, registration, classification, prediction, and generation. In this review, we provide an overview of the main machine learning methods used for MRI analysis, including supervised, unsupervised, and semi-supervised learning, as well as deep learning. We also discuss some of the current applications, limitations, and future directions of machine learning for MRI.
output: - Machine learning methods for MRI: a survey of current and future possibilities

input: The use of social media platforms such as Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram has become ubiquitous in today's society, especially among young adults. However, the psychological effects of these platforms on their users are not well understood. Previous studies have suggested that social media use may be associated with various mental health outcomes, such as depression, anxiety, loneliness, and self-esteem. However, the causal mechanisms and the directionality of these associations remain unclear. Moreover, most studies have focused on a single platform or a single outcome, neglecting the potential interactions and synergies among different platforms and outcomes. In this study, we aim to address these gaps by conducting a comprehensive and longitudinal analysis of the effects of social media use on mental health among young adults. We use a large-scale panel data set that tracks the social media use and mental health outcomes of over 10,000 young adults in the United States over four years. We employ various econometric methods, such as fixed effects models, instrumental variables, and mediation analysis, to identify the causal effects of social media use on mental health and to explore the underlying mechanisms. We also examine the heterogeneity of the effects across different platforms, outcomes, and subgroups of users. Our results provide novel insights into the complex and dynamic relationship between social media use and mental health among young adults, and have important implications for policy and practice.
output: - The impact of social media use on mental health: A four-year and multi-platform study of young adults in the United States

input: The use of social media platforms such as Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram has become ubiquitous in today's society. However, the impact of social media on mental health is still a controversial and understudied topic. Some studies suggest that social media can have positive effects on well-being, such as enhancing social support, self-expression, and learning. Other studies warn about the negative effects of social media, such as increased depression, anxiety, and cyberbullying. The aim of this paper is to provide a systematic review of the literature on the relationship between social media use and mental health outcomes. We searched four databases (PubMed, PsycINFO, Web of Science, and Scopus) for articles published between January 2010 and December 2019 that examined the association between social media use and various indicators of mental health, such as mood, self-esteem, loneliness, and suicidal behavior. We identified 148 studies that met our inclusion criteria and synthesized their findings using a narrative approach. The results showed that the relationship between social media use and mental health is complex and influenced by multiple factors, such as the type, frequency, and purpose of social media use, the content and quality of online interactions, and the characteristics and circumstances of the users. We also discussed the methodological limitations of the existing studies and suggested directions for future research.
output: - Exploring the Complex Relationship between Social Media Use and Mental Health Outcomes: A Systematic Review

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance and mood of older adults. Sixty healthy participants aged 60 to 75 years were randomly assigned to one of four music conditions: classical, jazz, pop, or silence. They completed a battery of cognitive tests measuring attention, memory, and executive functions, as well as a mood questionnaire, before and after listening to music for 15 minutes. The results showed that classical music improved spatial working memory and abstract reasoning, while jazz music enhanced verbal memory and fluency. Pop music and silence did not have any significant effects on cognition or mood. The mood questionnaire revealed that classical and jazz music increased positive affect and decreased negative affect, while pop music and silence had no impact on mood. These findings suggest that listening to music can be a simple and effective way to enhance cognitive functioning and emotional well-being in older adults, and that the type of music matters.
output: - Cognitive and mood enhancement by classical and jazz music in older adults: A music intervention study

input: The human gut microbiota is a complex and dynamic community of microorganisms that plays a key role in host health and disease. The composition and function of the gut microbiota are influenced by various factors, such as diet, genetics, environment, and medications. Among these, antibiotics are known to have a profound and lasting impact on the gut microbiota, leading to the disruption of its ecological balance and the emergence of antibiotic-resistant bacteria. However, the mechanisms by which antibiotics affect the gut microbiota and the consequences for host health are not fully understood. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the effects of antibiotics on the gut microbiota, focusing on the changes in microbial diversity, function, and resistance. We also discuss the potential implications of antibiotic-induced gut dysbiosis for various diseases, such as inflammatory bowel disease, obesity, diabetes, and allergic disorders. Finally, we highlight some of the strategies that can be used to prevent or mitigate the adverse effects of antibiotics on the gut microbiota, such as probiotics, prebiotics, synbiotics, fecal microbiota transplantation, and personalized medicine.
output: - Antibiotic-induced gut dysbiosis: mechanisms, outcomes, and remedies

input: The development of artificial neural networks (ANNs) has been one of the most influential advances in the field of artificial intelligence. ANNs are computational models inspired by the structure and function of biological neurons, capable of learning from data and performing complex tasks such as classification, regression, clustering, and generation. However, ANNs also face some challenges and limitations, such as the need for large amounts of data, the lack of interpretability and explainability, the vulnerability to adversarial attacks, and the ethical and social implications of their applications. In this review, we provide a comprehensive overview of the main concepts, architectures, applications, and challenges of ANNs, with a focus on the recent developments and trends in the field. We also discuss some of the open problems and future directions for the research and practice of ANNs.
output: - Learning from Data with Artificial Neural Networks: Achievements and Issues

input: Background: The gut microbiota plays a key role in human health and disease, but the mechanisms underlying its interactions with the host are not fully understood. One potential way to modulate the gut microbiota is through dietary interventions, such as prebiotics and probiotics. However, the effects of these interventions on the gut microbiota composition and function are highly variable and depend on several factors, such as the baseline microbiota, host genetics, and environmental factors. Objectives: To review the current evidence on the effects of prebiotics and probiotics on the gut microbiota and its implications for human health. Study Design: We searched PubMed, Scopus, and Cochrane databases for randomized controlled trials (RCTs) that assessed the effects of prebiotics and probiotics on the gut microbiota composition and function in healthy adults. We extracted data on the intervention type, dose, duration, outcome measures, and main findings. We also assessed the quality of the studies using the Cochrane risk of bias tool. Results: We included 42 RCTs that met our inclusion criteria. The majority of the studies used 16S rRNA gene sequencing to analyze the gut microbiota composition, while only a few studies measured the gut microbiota function using metagenomics, metabolomics, or other methods. The effects of prebiotics and probiotics on the gut microbiota were heterogeneous and depended on the intervention type, dose, duration, and baseline microbiota. Prebiotics generally increased the abundance of bifidobacteria and lactobacilli, while probiotics had more strain-specific effects. The effects of prebiotics and probiotics on the gut microbiota function were less consistent and often not correlated with the changes in the composition. The clinical relevance of the observed changes in the gut microbiota was unclear, as most studies did not measure health outcomes or did not find significant associations. Conclusions: Prebiotics and probiotics can modulate the gut microbiota composition and function in healthy adults, but the effects are variable and depend on several factors. More studies are needed to elucidate the mechanisms of prebiotic and probiotic actions, to identify the optimal doses and durations, and to evaluate the clinical benefits of these interventions.
output: - A systematic review of the effects of prebiotics and probiotics on the gut microbiota and its implications for human health in healthy adults

input: The gut microbiota is a complex and dynamic community of microorganisms that colonizes the gastrointestinal tract and influences various aspects of host physiology and health. The composition and function of the gut microbiota are shaped by multiple factors, including diet, genetics, environment, and host immunity. Dysbiosis of the gut microbiota, defined as an imbalance or perturbation in the microbial ecosystem, has been associated with various diseases, such as inflammatory bowel disease, obesity, diabetes, and cancer. However, the causal relationships and underlying mechanisms of microbiota-host interactions are not fully understood. Recent advances in sequencing technologies, bioinformatics, and animal models have enabled more comprehensive and integrative analyses of the gut microbiota and its impact on host metabolism, immunity, and behavior. This review summarizes the current knowledge and challenges of gut microbiota research, with a focus on the methods and tools for studying the microbiota, the factors that shape its composition and function, and the potential applications of microbiota modulation for disease prevention and treatment.
output: - The dynamic and diverse gut microbiota: implications for health and disease

input: The human gut microbiota plays a crucial role in various aspects of health and disease, such as metabolism, immunity, and neurodevelopment. However, the mechanisms by which the gut microbiota influences host physiology and behavior are not fully understood. One possible way is through the production of metabolites that can act as signaling molecules, modulating various cellular pathways and gene expression. In this review, we focus on the gut microbiota-derived metabolites that have been implicated in the regulation of host circadian rhythms, sleep, and mood. We discuss how these metabolites interact with different receptors and enzymes, such as G protein-coupled receptors, nuclear receptors, and histone deacetylases, to affect the expression and activity of clock genes, neurotransmitters, and hormones. We also highlight the potential therapeutic applications of manipulating the gut microbiota or its metabolites for the treatment of circadian and mood disorders.
output: - Gut microbiota metabolites and their interactions with host receptors and enzymes: implications for circadian and mood disorders

input: Background: The COVID-19 pandemic has posed unprecedented challenges to the health systems worldwide, especially in terms of diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of the disease. Rapid and accurate testing for SARS-CoV-2, the causative agent of COVID-19, is essential for controlling the transmission and providing appropriate care for the patients. However, the current diagnostic methods, such as reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and antigen detection, have some limitations, such as high cost, low availability, long turnaround time, and variable sensitivity. Therefore, there is an urgent need for developing alternative and complementary methods for COVID-19 diagnosis. Results: In this study, we propose a novel method based on the detection of SARS-CoV-2 specific antibodies in saliva samples using a microfluidic immunoassay. The microfluidic device consists of a paper-based strip embedded with a nitrocellulose membrane that contains two test lines: one coated with recombinant SARS-CoV-2 spike protein and the other with human IgG. The saliva sample is mixed with a buffer containing gold nanoparticles conjugated with anti-human IgM and IgG, and then loaded into the device. The presence of SARS-CoV-2 specific antibodies in the saliva sample results in the formation of a visible red line on the test line within 15 minutes. The intensity of the test line is proportional to the antibody level in the sample and can be quantified by a smartphone app. The device also has a control line that indicates the proper functioning of the assay. Conclusions: The microfluidic immunoassay for SARS-CoV-2 antibody detection in saliva samples offers a simple, rapid, low-cost, and non-invasive alternative to the conventional methods for COVID-19 diagnosis. The device can be used for large-scale screening, surveillance, and monitoring of the disease progression and immune response in different populations. The device can also be adapted for the detection of other infectious agents by changing the test line antigen.
output: - Detection of SARS-CoV-2 antibodies in saliva by a microfluidic immunoassay with recombinant spike protein and smartphone app

input: The human gut microbiota is a complex and dynamic community of microorganisms that plays a key role in health and disease. The composition and function of the gut microbiota are influenced by various factors, including diet, genetics, environment, and host immunity. However, the mechanisms by which these factors shape the gut microbiota and its interactions with the host are not fully understood. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the factors that affect the gut microbiota and its impact on host health, with a focus on inflammatory bowel diseases (IBDs), obesity, and metabolic syndrome. We also discuss the potential of manipulating the gut microbiota through dietary interventions, prebiotics, probiotics, and fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) as novel therapeutic strategies for these disorders. We highlight the challenges and limitations of these approaches, as well as the future directions and perspectives for gut microbiota research and application.
output: - The dynamic and complex gut microbiota: from influencing factors to therapeutic potential in inflammatory and metabolic conditions

input: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of different types of music on the stress levels and milk yield of dairy cows. A total of 117 Holstein cows were randomly assigned to one of three treatments: classical music, rock music, or no music. The music was played for 12 hours per day, from 7:00 to 19:00, for four weeks. The stress levels of the cows were assessed by measuring cortisol concentrations in milk and saliva, as well as heart rate variability. The milk yield was recorded daily and the milk composition was analyzed weekly. The results showed that cows exposed to classical music had significantly lower cortisol levels, higher heart rate variability, and higher milk yield than cows exposed to rock music or no music. The milk composition was not affected by the music treatments. The findings suggest that classical music can be used as a tool to reduce stress and improve welfare and productivity of dairy cows. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.applanim.2018.02.021
output: - How music influences stress levels and milk performance of Holstein cows

input: The use of social media platforms such as Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram has grown exponentially in recent years, creating new opportunities and challenges for health communication. Social media can be used to disseminate health information, to foster social support and peer interaction, to promote health behaviors and interventions, and to monitor and respond to public health emergencies. However, social media also poses risks for health communication, such as misinformation, privacy breaches, cyberbullying, and online addiction. In this paper, we review the current state of the art of social media research in health communication, focusing on four key areas: health promotion, health education, health crisis communication, and health surveillance. We discuss the theoretical and methodological issues, the ethical and legal implications, and the future directions and challenges for social media research in health communication. We conclude that social media offers great potential for enhancing health communication, but also requires careful and responsible use and regulation.
output: - How social media shapes health communication: a review of theory, methods, ethics, and challenges

input: We investigated the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance and mood of healthy older adults. Sixty participants completed a battery of neuropsychological tests and mood scales under three conditions: classical music, rock music, and silence. The results showed that classical music enhanced verbal memory and visuospatial abilities, while rock music impaired verbal memory and had no effect on visuospatial abilities. Both types of music improved mood, but rock music increased arousal more than classical music. The findings suggest that music can have both beneficial and detrimental effects on cognitive functions, depending on the type, tempo, and volume of the music, as well as the task and the individual preferences of the listener.
output: - Music genre, cognitive performance, and mood in healthy older adults

input: The development of artificial intelligence (AI) has brought significant benefits to various fields of human endeavor, such as medicine, education, and entertainment. However, it also poses serious ethical challenges, such as the potential impact of AI on human dignity, autonomy, and privacy. Moreover, the increasing use of AI in decision-making and governance raises questions about the accountability, transparency, and fairness of AI systems. In this paper, we review the main ethical issues related to AI, and discuss the existing frameworks and principles for ethical AI. We also examine the limitations and challenges of these approaches, and propose some directions for future research and practice. We argue that ethical AI requires not only technical solutions, but also interdisciplinary collaboration, stakeholder engagement, and public education.
output: - Ethical Challenges and Solutions for Artificial Intelligence Systems

input: The human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) envelope glycoprotein (Env) is the main target of neutralizing antibodies and vaccine design. Env is composed of a surface subunit (gp120) and a transmembrane subunit (gp41) that mediate viral entry by fusing the viral and host membranes. Env undergoes conformational changes during the entry process, exposing transiently the fusion peptide (FP) at the N-terminus of gp41, which inserts into the target membrane. The FP is highly conserved among HIV-1 isolates and plays a crucial role in membrane fusion. However, the structure and dynamics of the FP in its membrane-bound state are not well understood. In this study, we used molecular dynamics simulations to investigate the interaction of the FP with different lipid bilayers, mimicking the viral and host membranes. We found that the FP adopts a tilted orientation with respect to the membrane normal, forming an oblique angle that varies depending on the lipid composition and curvature of the bilayer. We also observed that the FP induces local membrane thinning and lipid disorder, creating a fusion-favorable environment. Our findings provide new insights into the molecular mechanism of HIV-1 entry and suggest that the FP could be a potential target for antiviral agents.
output: - The role of the HIV-1 fusion peptide in membrane fusion: structure, dynamics and implications for antiviral design

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance of older adults. Sixty healthy participants aged 60 to 75 years were randomly assigned to one of four groups: classical music, rock music, white noise, or silence. They performed a series of tasks that measured attention, memory, executive function, and mood. The results showed that classical music enhanced both attention and memory, while rock music impaired attention and executive function. White noise had no significant effect on any cognitive measure. Mood was not affected by any type of music. These findings suggest that music can have both beneficial and detrimental effects on the cognitive abilities of older adults, depending on the genre and the task.
output: - Differential effects of music genre on cognitive abilities of older adults

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance and mood of older adults. Sixty healthy participants (aged 60-83 years) were randomly assigned to one of four music conditions: classical, jazz, pop, or silence. They completed a battery of cognitive tests measuring memory, attention, and executive functions, as well as a mood questionnaire, before and after listening to music for 15 minutes. The results showed that listening to classical music improved spatial working memory and abstract reasoning, while listening to jazz music improved verbal memory and fluency. Listening to pop music or silence did not have any significant effects on cognition or mood. The mood ratings indicated that classical and jazz music induced positive affect and relaxation, while pop music and silence did not. These findings suggest that music can enhance cognitive performance and mood in older adults, depending on the genre of music. The possible mechanisms underlying the music-cognition relationship and the implications for music interventions in aging are discussed.
output: - Music as a cognitive enhancer and mood regulator in aging: The role of music genre

input: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of a mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) on the psychological well-being and quality of life of patients with chronic pain. A randomized controlled trial was conducted with 60 patients who met the criteria for chronic pain. They were randomly assigned to either an MBI group or a wait-list control group. The MBI group received an 8-week program consisting of weekly group sessions and daily home practice of mindfulness exercises. The control group received usual care and was offered the MBI after the study. The primary outcome measures were pain intensity, pain acceptance, depression, anxiety, and quality of life. The secondary outcome measures were mindfulness, self-compassion, and pain catastrophizing. Assessments were conducted at baseline, post-intervention, and 3-month follow-up. The results showed that the MBI group had significantly lower pain intensity, depression, anxiety, and pain catastrophizing, and significantly higher pain acceptance, quality of life, mindfulness, and self-compassion than the control group at post-intervention and follow-up. The MBI group also showed significant improvements in all outcome measures from baseline to post-intervention and follow-up. The control group showed no significant changes in any outcome measures. The MBI was well received by the participants and had a high retention rate. The findings suggest that MBI is a feasible and effective intervention for improving the psychological well-being and quality of life of patients with chronic pain.
output: - Mindfulness-based intervention reduces pain and enhances well-being in chronic pain patients: A randomized controlled trial

input: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of different types of music on the stress levels and immune responses of patients undergoing coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG). Sixty patients were randomly assigned to one of three groups: classical music, new age music, or no music. The patients listened to the music via headphones for 30 minutes before and after the surgery. Blood samples were collected to measure cortisol, interleukin-6, and natural killer cell activity. The results showed that the classical music group had significantly lower cortisol levels and higher natural killer cell activity than the other two groups. The new age music group had significantly lower interleukin-6 levels than the no music group. There were no significant differences in anxiety or pain scores among the groups. These findings suggest that music may have beneficial effects on the stress and immune responses of CABG patients.
output: - Classical music lowers cortisol and boosts natural killer cells in CABG patients: a randomized controlled study

input: The human gut microbiota is a complex ecosystem that plays a crucial role in health and disease. The composition and function of the gut microbiota are influenced by various factors, such as diet, genetics, environment, and host immunity. Dysbiosis of the gut microbiota has been associated with various diseases, such as inflammatory bowel disease, obesity, diabetes, and cancer. However, the mechanisms by which the gut microbiota modulates host physiology and pathology are not fully understood. Metabolomics is a powerful tool to study the metabolic interactions between the gut microbiota and the host, as it can capture the dynamic changes of metabolites in biological samples. Metabolomics can provide insights into the functional role of the gut microbiota and its contribution to host health and disease. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the application of metabolomics in gut microbiota research, focusing on the analytical methods, data analysis, and biological interpretation. We also discuss the challenges and future perspectives of metabolomics in this emerging field.
output: - The gut microbiota and its metabolites: a metabolomics perspective

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on cognitive performance and mood in healthy older adults. Sixty participants (aged 60-84 years) were randomly assigned to one of four music conditions: classical, jazz, pop, or no music. They completed a battery of cognitive tests measuring attention, memory, and executive functions, as well as a mood questionnaire, before and after listening to music for 15 minutes. The results showed that classical music improved spatial working memory and verbal fluency, jazz music enhanced verbal memory and mental flexibility, and pop music increased processing speed and mood. No music condition did not show any significant changes in cognitive performance or mood. The findings suggest that listening to different genres of music can selectively affect different cognitive abilities and mood states in older adults.
output: - Cognitive and mood benefits of listening to classical, jazz, and pop music in older adults

input: Background: The use of social media platforms such as Twitter has become widespread in public health and epidemiology. However, the reliability and validity of the data obtained from these sources are often questionable, as they may be influenced by various factors such as user demographics, sentiment, and topic popularity. Methods: We propose a novel framework for assessing the quality of Twitter data for disease surveillance, based on a combination of content analysis, network analysis, and machine learning techniques. We apply our framework to a case study of COVID-19, using a large dataset of tweets collected from January to April 2020. We extract relevant features from the tweets, such as keywords, hashtags, mentions, retweets, and URLs, and use them to construct a heterogeneous network that captures the semantic and social relationships among the Twitter users and content. We then use a semi-supervised node classification algorithm to label the nodes in the network as high-quality or low-quality, based on a set of criteria derived from the literature. Results: We evaluate the performance of our framework using various metrics, such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score, and compare it with several baseline methods. We also analyze the characteristics of the high-quality and low-quality nodes, and identify the factors that contribute to the quality assessment. We find that our framework can effectively distinguish between high-quality and low-quality Twitter data, and that the network features are more informative than the content features for this task. Conclusion: Our study demonstrates the feasibility and utility of using network analysis and machine learning for quality assessment of Twitter data for disease surveillance. Our framework can be used to filter out noisy and irrelevant data, and to enhance the signal and credibility of the data. This can improve the accuracy and timeliness of disease outbreak detection and monitoring, and provide valuable insights for public health decision making.
output: - Network analysis and machine learning for quality filtering of Twitter data for COVID-19 surveillance

input: The development of novel therapies for Alzheimer's disease (AD) is hampered by the lack of reliable biomarkers for early diagnosis and disease progression. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) amyloid-beta (Aβ) and tau proteins are currently the most validated AD biomarkers, but their invasive and costly collection limits their clinical utility. Blood-based biomarkers, such as plasma Aβ and tau, have emerged as promising alternatives, but their accuracy and consistency across studies are still under debate. In this review, we summarize the current state of the art of blood-based AD biomarkers, focusing on the analytical methods, the pre-analytical and biological factors, and the clinical applications of plasma Aβ and tau measurements. We also discuss the potential of novel blood-based biomarkers, such as microRNAs, exosomes, and autoantibodies, as well as the challenges and opportunities for biomarker validation and standardization. We conclude that blood-based AD biomarkers have great potential for improving the diagnosis and monitoring of AD, but further research and harmonization are needed to achieve their full clinical translation. (183 words)
output: - The potential and pitfalls of blood-based biomarkers for Alzheimer's disease: a focus on plasma Aβ and tau

input: The human gut microbiota is a complex ecosystem that plays an important role in health and disease. The composition and function of the gut microbiota are influenced by various factors, such as diet, genetics, environment, and host immunity. However, the mechanisms by which these factors shape the gut microbiota and its interactions with the host are not fully understood. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the factors that affect the gut microbiota and their impact on various aspects of human health, such as metabolism, immunity, inflammation, and susceptibility to infections. We also discuss the potential applications of gut microbiota modulation for the prevention and treatment of diseases, such as obesity, diabetes, inflammatory bowel disease, and colorectal cancer. Finally, we highlight the challenges and limitations of gut microbiota research and suggest future directions for this emerging field.
output: - The impact of host and environmental factors on the gut microbiota and its role in metabolism, immunity, inflammation, and infection

input: Background: The emergence and spread of multidrug-resistant (MDR) bacteria pose a serious threat to public health worldwide. Among the MDR pathogens, Acinetobacter baumannii is of particular concern as it causes severe infections in hospitalized patients and has remarkable abilities to acquire resistance to various classes of antibiotics. Colistin is considered as the last-resort antibiotic for the treatment of infections caused by MDR A. baumannii. However, colistin-resistant isolates have been increasingly reported in recent years, limiting the therapeutic options for this problematic pathogen. Methods: In this study, we investigated the molecular mechanisms and fitness costs of colistin resistance in a collection of 51 clinical A. baumannii isolates from China. We performed antimicrobial susceptibility testing, multilocus sequence typing, PCR screening of resistance genes, whole-genome sequencing, and growth curve analysis. Results: We identified 17 colistin-resistant isolates belonging to 11 different sequence types. The most prevalent mechanism of colistin resistance was the modification of the lipid A component of lipopolysaccharide (LPS) mediated by the phosphoethanolamine transferase gene lpxE, which was located on the chromosome in 13 isolates and on a plasmid in one isolate. Other mechanisms included the loss or modification of LPS due to mutations in the lpxA, lpxC, lpxD, and lpsB genes. Additionally, we found that colistin resistance was associated with significant fitness costs in terms of growth rate, biofilm formation, and motility. Conclusion: Our study revealed the diversity and complexity of colistin resistance mechanisms in A. baumannii and the trade-offs between resistance and fitness that may influence the persistence and spread of colistin-resistant strains.
output: - Colistin resistance in Acinetobacter baumannii: genetic determinants, sequence types, and fitness consequences

input: The human gut microbiota is a complex ecosystem that plays an important role in health and disease. The composition and function of the microbiota are influenced by various factors, such as diet, environment, host genetics, and immune system. Dysbiosis of the microbiota has been associated with various disorders, such as inflammatory bowel disease, obesity, diabetes, and cancer. However, the mechanisms by which the microbiota modulates host physiology and pathology are not fully understood. One of the emerging topics in microbiota research is the role of extracellular vesicles (EVs) as mediators of intercellular communication between the microbiota and the host. EVs are membrane-bound nanoparticles that can carry various biomolecules, such as proteins, lipids, nucleic acids, and metabolites. EVs can be released by both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells and can affect the function of target cells by transferring their cargo. This review summarizes the current knowledge on the production, characterization, and biological effects of EVs derived from the gut microbiota and their potential implications for human health and disease.
output: - Gut microbiota and extracellular vesicles: a complex interplay with consequences for health and disease

input: The human gut microbiota is a complex and dynamic ecosystem that plays a key role in health and disease. The composition and function of the gut microbiota are influenced by multiple factors, including diet, host genetics, environmental exposures, and medications. Among these, antibiotics are known to have profound and lasting effects on the gut microbiota, altering its diversity, structure, and metabolic potential. However, the mechanisms by which antibiotics affect the gut microbiota and the consequences for host health are not fully understood. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the impact of antibiotics on the gut microbiota, focusing on the effects of different classes, doses, and durations of antibiotic treatment. We also discuss the potential implications of antibiotic-induced dysbiosis for various diseases, such as inflammatory bowel disease, obesity, diabetes, and infections. Finally, we highlight the challenges and opportunities for future research in this field, as well as the potential strategies to restore or modulate the gut microbiota after antibiotic exposure.
output: - Antibiotics and the human gut microbiota: a complex and dynamic interaction

input: The development of novel antiviral agents is crucial for the treatment and prevention of viral infections, especially those caused by emerging and re-emerging pathogens. Among the different strategies to inhibit viral replication, targeting viral proteases is one of the most successful and widely used. Viral proteases are essential enzymes that cleave viral polyproteins into functional units, and their inhibition can result in non-infectious viral particles. However, viral proteases are also highly diverse and prone to mutations that confer resistance to existing inhibitors. Therefore, there is a constant need for the discovery and optimization of new protease inhibitors with broad-spectrum activity and high specificity. In this review, we summarize the current state of the art in the design and development of viral protease inhibitors, focusing on the main challenges and opportunities in this field. We discuss the different approaches and techniques used to identify, characterize, and optimize protease inhibitors, as well as the main structural and functional features of viral proteases that can be exploited for drug design. We also highlight some of the most promising candidates and perspectives for the future of antiviral therapy based on protease inhibition.
output: - Antiviral drug discovery based on viral protease inhibition: a comprehensive overview

input: The development of artificial neural networks (ANNs) has revolutionized various fields of science and engineering, enabling applications such as image recognition, natural language processing, and self-driving cars. However, the design and optimization of ANNs remain challenging tasks that often require extensive trial-and-error and expert knowledge. To address this issue, we propose a novel framework for automated neural architecture search (NAS) based on quantum annealing (QA), a metaheuristic for finding the global minimum of a given objective function. We formulate the NAS problem as a quadratic unconstrained binary optimization (QUBO) problem, which can be solved by QA, and introduce a penalty term to enforce the validity of the network architectures. We also propose a method to reduce the number of binary variables in the QUBO formulation by exploiting the symmetry of the problem. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on two benchmark datasets, MNIST and CIFAR-10, and compare it with other NAS methods based on genetic algorithms and Bayesian optimization. We show that our method can find high-performing and compact network architectures with fewer evaluations and shorter running time than the competing methods. We also analyze the impact of the penalty term and the variable reduction method on the performance of our method. Our results suggest that QA is a promising technique for NAS and that our framework can be extended to other types of ANNs and optimization problems.
output: - Quantum Annealing and QUBO: A New Paradigm for Automated Neural Architecture Search

input: The development of novel anticancer agents is a major challenge in drug discovery. Among the natural products, marine-derived compounds have attracted considerable attention due to their structural diversity and biological activity. In particular, marine alkaloids have emerged as a promising class of anticancer agents with various modes of action and molecular targets. Some of them have entered clinical trials or have been approved as anticancer drugs. However, the limited supply, structural complexity, and undesirable side effects of some marine alkaloids have hampered their clinical application and stimulated the search for new analogues with improved potency and selectivity. In this review, we summarize the recent advances in the discovery, synthesis, and evaluation of marine alkaloids and their analogues as anticancer agents. We focus on the structure-activity relationship, mechanism of action, and therapeutic potential of the most representative marine alkaloids, such as ecteinascidins, ascididemins, lamellarins, lepadins, aplysinopsins, zoanthamines, and fascaplysin. We also discuss the challenges and opportunities for the development of marine alkaloid-based anticancer drugs.
output: - Marine alkaloids as natural scaffolds for the design of novel anticancer compounds

input: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid and accurate diagnostic tests for viral infections. Loop-mediated isothermal amplification (LAMP) is a nucleic acid amplification technique that can be performed with minimal equipment and has been widely used for detection of various pathogens. However, LAMP still requires sample preparation steps that may limit its point-of-care applications. Here, we report a simple and rapid method for direct LAMP detection of SARS-CoV-2 from nasopharyngeal swabs without RNA extraction. We optimized the LAMP reaction conditions to achieve detection within 15 minutes and evaluated the clinical performance of our method using 100 swab samples from COVID-19 patients. We found that our method has a sensitivity of 90% and a specificity of 100%, comparable to those of reverse transcription-PCR (RT-PCR). We also demonstrate that our method can be coupled with a lateral flow device or a pH indicator for visual detection of LAMP products. Our method provides a low-cost, fast, and easy-to-use diagnostic tool for COVID-19, especially in resource-limited settings.
output: - Extraction-free loop-mediated isothermal amplification: a novel diagnostic tool for COVID-19 with high sensitivity and specificity

input: The aim of this paper is to investigate the impact of social media on political participation and civic engagement in the Arab world. The paper examines the use of Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, and other platforms by activists, journalists, and ordinary citizens during the Arab Spring uprisings that started in late 2010 and spread across the region. The paper also explores the challenges and opportunities that social media present for democracy and human rights in the Arab world. The paper adopts a mixed-methods approach, combining quantitative data from online surveys and qualitative data from interviews and content analysis. The paper argues that social media played a significant role in mobilizing, organizing, and informing the protesters, as well as in creating transnational solidarity and awareness. However, the paper also acknowledges the limitations and drawbacks of social media, such as censorship, surveillance, misinformation, and polarization. The paper concludes that social media are not a panacea for the political and social problems of the Arab world, but rather a tool that can be used for various purposes, depending on the context and the actors involved.
output: - The Impact of Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube on the Arab Spring: A Multi-Method Analysis

input: The human gut microbiota is a complex and dynamic community of microorganisms that plays a key role in host health and disease. The composition and function of the gut microbiota are influenced by multiple factors, including diet, genetics, environment, and medications. Among these, diet is one of the most important and modifiable factors that can shape the gut microbiota and its metabolic output. Dietary interventions, such as prebiotics, probiotics, synbiotics, and fecal microbiota transplantation, have been proposed as potential strategies to modulate the gut microbiota and improve host health. However, the effects of these interventions are often variable and depend on the individual's baseline microbiota, dietary habits, and host characteristics. Therefore, there is a need for personalized approaches that can optimize the gut microbiota for each individual and enhance the efficacy of dietary interventions. In this review, we summarize the current evidence on the effects of dietary interventions on the gut microbiota and host health, and discuss the challenges and opportunities for developing personalized nutrition based on the gut microbiota.
output: - Personalized nutrition based on the gut microbiota: a review of the effects and variability of dietary interventions on host health

input: The human gut microbiota is a complex and dynamic ecosystem that plays a key role in health and disease. The composition and function of the gut microbiota are influenced by multiple factors, including diet, genetics, environment, and host immunity. Dysbiosis, or imbalance of the gut microbiota, has been associated with various chronic inflammatory and metabolic disorders, such as inflammatory bowel disease, obesity, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease. However, the causal relationships and underlying mechanisms of these associations are not fully understood. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the interactions between the gut microbiota and the host immune system, focusing on how the microbiota modulates the development and function of innate and adaptive immune cells. We also discuss the potential applications of microbiota-targeted interventions, such as probiotics, prebiotics, and fecal microbiota transplantation, for the prevention and treatment of immune-mediated diseases.
output: - Gut microbiota-immune system interactions and their impact on inflammatory and metabolic disorders

input: In this paper, we propose a novel approach to generate natural language summaries of source code snippets. Our approach leverages the syntactic and semantic information of the code, as well as the natural language comments and identifiers, to produce concise and informative summaries. We use a neural encoder-decoder model with attention mechanism to encode the code elements and decode the natural language summary. We also introduce a new dataset of Python code snippets and their summaries, collected from online sources and manually annotated by experts. We evaluate our approach on this dataset and compare it with several baselines, including a state-of-the-art code summarization method. The results show that our approach outperforms the baselines in terms of both automatic and human evaluation metrics, and can generate summaries that capture the main functionality and purpose of the code snippets.
output: - Neural Code Summarization with Attention and Code Elements

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance and mood of older adults. Sixty healthy participants aged 60-75 years were randomly assigned to one of four music conditions: classical, jazz, pop, or silence. They completed a battery of cognitive tests measuring attention, memory, and executive functions, as well as a mood questionnaire, before and after listening to music for 15 minutes. The results showed that classical music improved spatial working memory and verbal fluency, while jazz music enhanced verbal memory and mental flexibility. Pop music and silence did not have any significant effects on cognition or mood. The mood ratings indicated that classical and jazz music increased positive affect and decreased negative affect, while pop music and silence had no impact on mood. These findings suggest that listening to music can modulate cognitive functions and mood in older adults, depending on the genre of music. The possible mechanisms and implications of these effects are discussed.
output: - The impact of music on attention, memory, executive functions, and mood in older adults: A genre-specific analysis

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the stress levels and immune responses of patients undergoing coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery. Sixty patients were randomly assigned to one of three groups: classical music, new age music, or no music. The patients in the music groups listened to the assigned music through headphones for 30 minutes before and after the surgery. Blood samples were collected to measure cortisol, interleukin-6, and immunoglobulin A levels. The patients also completed the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory and a visual analog scale for pain.
