The reduction in neutralization was more pronounced for the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine than for the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, especially against the B.1.351 variant. We also evaluated the potential of sera from vaccinated individuals to enhance the infection of Fc receptor-expressing cells, a phenomenon known as antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE). We did not observe any evidence of ADE in any of the variants tested. Our results suggest that current vaccines may offer less protection against variants with mutations in the spike protein and highlight the need for continuous monitoring of vaccine efficacy and virus evolution.
output: - Vaccine efficacy and virus evolution: a study of neutralization and ADE of SARS-CoV-2 variants by sera from vaccinated individuals

input: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of different types of music on the stress levels and milk yield of dairy cows. A total of 117 Holstein cows were randomly assigned to one of three treatments: classical music (CM), rock music (RM), or no music (NM). The music was played for 12 hours per day, from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m., for 60 consecutive days. The stress levels of the cows were assessed by measuring cortisol concentrations in milk and saliva, as well as behavioral indicators such as lying time, rumination time, and ear position. The milk yield and composition were also recorded daily. The results showed that CM significantly reduced the cortisol levels in milk and saliva, increased the lying and rumination time, and induced more relaxed ear positions compared to NM and RM. CM also increased the milk yield and improved the milk composition by enhancing the fat and protein content. RM had the opposite effects, increasing the stress levels, reducing the lying and rumination time, and inducing more alert ear positions. RM also decreased the milk yield and deteriorated the milk composition by reducing the fat and protein content. NM had intermediate effects between CM and RM. These findings suggest that music can modulate the stress levels and milk production of dairy cows, and that the type of music is important to consider. Classical music can be used as a tool to improve the welfare and productivity of dairy cows, while rock music should be avoided.
output: - How music influences the welfare and productivity of dairy cows

input: The development of artificial intelligence (AI) has brought significant benefits to various fields of human endeavor, such as education, health, entertainment, and security. However, AI also poses serious ethical challenges that need to be addressed to ensure its responsible and trustworthy use. These challenges include issues such as fairness, accountability, transparency, privacy, human dignity, and social justice. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive overview of the main ethical issues raised by AI, and the existing frameworks and principles that aim to guide its ethical design and governance. We also discuss some of the limitations and gaps of these frameworks, and propose some directions for future research and action. We argue that ethical AI requires not only the alignment of AI systems with human values, but also the empowerment of human users and the protection of human rights in the face of AI's potential harms. Furthermore, we suggest that ethical AI should be developed and deployed in a participatory and inclusive manner, involving diverse stakeholders and perspectives, and respecting the cultural and contextual diversity of human societies.
output: - Ethical Issues and Frameworks for Artificial Intelligence: A Critical and Inclusive Perspective

input: The development of novel antimicrobial agents is essential to combat the increasing threat of multidrug-resistant bacteria. Peptides are promising candidates for new antibiotics, as they can exhibit potent and selective activity against various pathogens. However, the design of effective peptide antibiotics is challenging, as they need to balance several physicochemical properties, such as hydrophobicity, amphipathicity, and net charge. In this study, we applied a machine learning approach to generate and optimize peptide sequences with desired antimicrobial properties. We used a recurrent neural network (RNN) to learn the patterns of naturally occurring antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) and to generate novel peptide sequences. We then screened the generated peptides for their antimicrobial activity, stability, and toxicity using a combination of computational and experimental methods. We identified several novel peptides that showed potent activity against Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus, as well as low hemolytic activity and high serum stability. Furthermore, we demonstrated that the RNN model can be fine-tuned to generate peptides with specific properties, such as increased hydrophobicity or net charge. Our results show that machine learning can be a useful tool for the discovery and optimization of novel peptide antibiotics.
output: - Learning from nature: a recurrent neural network model for designing effective antimicrobial peptides

input: The development of effective vaccines against COVID-19 is a global priority, but the potential immune correlates of protection are not well defined. Neutralizing antibodies (NAbs) are likely to play an important role in preventing infection and disease, but their durability, breadth and relationship with other immune responses are unclear. Here, we report a longitudinal analysis of NAbs and T cell responses in 136 healthcare workers who received two doses of the BNT162b2 mRNA vaccine. We found that NAb titers peaked at 21 days after the second dose and declined slightly thereafter, with an estimated half-life of 209 days. NAb titers correlated positively with spike-specific IgG and IgA levels, but not with T cell responses. We also assessed the neutralization activity of vaccine-induced antibodies against a panel of SARS-CoV-2 variants, including B.1.1.7, B.1.351, P.1 and B.1.617.2. We found that NAb titers were reduced by 2.9- to 6.5-fold against these variants compared to the ancestral strain, but remained above the levels expected to confer protection. Our results suggest that the BNT162b2 vaccine elicits durable and broad NAb responses, which are likely to contribute to the high efficacy of the vaccine against diverse SARS-CoV-2 variants.
output: - Neutralization of SARS-CoV-2 variants by antibodies induced by the BNT162b2 mRNA vaccine in healthcare workers

input: The human microbiome is the collection of microorganisms that live in and on the human body, and it plays a crucial role in health and disease. The microbiome can be influenced by various factors, such as diet, lifestyle, environment, and medication. However, the mechanisms by which these factors shape the microbiome and its functions are not fully understood. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the interactions between the microbiome and some of the most common drugs used in clinical practice, such as antibiotics, proton pump inhibitors, metformin, and statins. We discuss how these drugs can alter the composition, diversity, and metabolic activity of the microbiome, and how these changes can affect the host's health and response to therapy. We also highlight the potential of using microbiome-based interventions, such as probiotics, prebiotics, and fecal microbiota transplantation, to modulate the microbiome and improve drug efficacy and safety.
output: - Drug-induced alterations of the human microbiome: challenges and solutions

input: Background: Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by impairments in social communication and interaction, and restricted and repetitive behaviors. The etiology of ASD is complex and heterogeneous, involving both genetic and environmental factors. Recent advances in genomic technologies have enabled the identification of hundreds of genes associated with ASD, many of which are involved in synaptic function and neuronal connectivity. However, the molecular mechanisms underlying ASD pathogenesis remain largely unknown. Methods: In this review, we summarize the current state of knowledge on the genetic basis of ASD, focusing on the synaptic genes that have been implicated in ASD. We also discuss the potential roles of these genes in synaptic function and plasticity, and how their dysfunction may lead to the core features of ASD. Results: Synaptic genes associated with ASD can be classified into several functional categories, such as synaptic adhesion, scaffolding, signaling, neurotransmission, and epigenetic regulation. These genes modulate various aspects of synaptic structure and function, such as synapse formation, maturation, maintenance, and plasticity. Dysregulation of these genes may affect the balance between excitatory and inhibitory neurotransmission, the formation and refinement of neural circuits, and the activity-dependent modulation of synaptic strength and connectivity. Conclusion: Synaptic genes play critical roles in the development and function of the brain, and their disruption may contribute to the pathophysiology of ASD. Understanding the synaptic mechanisms of ASD may provide novel insights into the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of this disorder.
output: - Genetic and synaptic basis of autism spectrum disorder: a review

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on cognitive performance and mood in healthy older adults. Sixty participants (aged 60-85 years) completed a battery of neuropsychological tests and mood scales under three conditions: listening to classical music, listening to rock music, or sitting in silence. The results showed that classical music enhanced performance on tasks of verbal memory, visuospatial ability, and processing speed, while rock music impaired performance on these tasks. Both types of music improved mood compared to silence, but classical music had a more positive effect on mood than rock music. The findings suggest that music can have both beneficial and detrimental effects on cognitive functions and mood in older adults, depending on the genre and the task.
output: - Music genre matters: differential effects of classical and rock music on cognition and mood in older adults

input: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of dietary supplementation with Lactobacillus rhamnosus GG (LGG) on the growth performance, intestinal morphology, and gut microbiota of broiler chickens challenged with Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium (ST). A total of 240 one-day-old broiler chicks were randomly assigned to four groups: negative control (NC), positive control (PC), PC + LGG (1 × 10^8 CFU/g of feed), and PC + LGG (1 × 10^9 CFU/g of feed). At 14 days of age, the PC and LGG groups were orally inoculated with 1 × 10^8 CFU of ST, while the NC group received sterile phosphate-buffered saline. The results showed that LGG supplementation improved the average daily gain and feed conversion ratio of broilers at 1–28 days of age. LGG also alleviated the ST-induced intestinal injury and reduced the ST counts in the cecal contents. Moreover, LGG modulated the cecal microbiota composition by increasing the abundance of beneficial bacteria (such as Lactobacillus, Bifidobacterium, and Ruminococcaceae) and decreasing the abundance of harmful bacteria (such as Escherichia-Shigella and Enterobacteriaceae). These findings suggest that dietary supplementation with LGG can enhance the growth performance and intestinal health of broiler chickens infected with ST.
output: - Lactobacillus rhamnosus GG enhances growth and intestinal health of broiler chickens by reducing Salmonella Typhimurium and altering cecal microbiota

input: The development of effective vaccines against infectious diseases is one of the greatest achievements of modern medicine. However, many pathogens, such as HIV, malaria, and tuberculosis, remain a major challenge for vaccine development, partly due to the high genetic diversity and antigenic variation of these pathogens. To overcome this obstacle, a novel vaccine design strategy, called mosaic vaccines, has been proposed. Mosaic vaccines are composed of artificial antigens that are optimized to maximize the coverage of potential T cell epitopes from natural pathogen sequences. Several computational methods have been developed to design mosaic antigens, such as MosaicBuilder, MosaikAligner, and OptiMosaic. These methods use different algorithms and criteria to select and assemble the optimal mosaic antigens from a large pool of natural sequences. In this review, we summarize the principles, advantages, and limitations of these methods, and compare their performance and applicability for different pathogens. We also discuss the challenges and future directions for mosaic vaccine design, such as incorporating B cell epitopes, improving immunogenicity and safety, and evaluating efficacy in animal models and clinical trials.
output: - Mosaic antigens for vaccine development: principles, methods, and applications

input: We have developed a novel method for the synthesis of gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) using a plant extract of Eclipta prostrata as both a reducing and stabilizing agent. The formation of AuNPs was confirmed by UV-visible spectroscopy, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). The synthesized AuNPs showed a surface plasmon resonance peak at 540 nm and were spherical in shape with an average size of 15 nm. The XRD pattern revealed the face-centered cubic structure of AuNPs and the FTIR analysis indicated the presence of phytochemicals such as phenols, terpenoids, and flavonoids on the surface of AuNPs. The synthesized AuNPs exhibited excellent catalytic activity in the reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol by sodium borohydride in aqueous medium. The reaction followed a pseudo-first-order kinetics and the apparent rate constant increased with increasing the amount of AuNPs. The catalytic activity of AuNPs was also compared with that of a commercial gold catalyst and found to be superior. The AuNPs were stable and reusable for several cycles without significant loss of activity. Thus, we have demonstrated a simple, green, and efficient method for the synthesis of AuNPs using Eclipta prostrata extract and their application as a nanocatalyst for the reduction of nitrophenols.
output: - A novel method for the synthesis of gold nanoparticles using Eclipta prostrata extract and their application as a reusable nanocatalyst for the reduction of 4-nitrophenol

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance and mood of older adults. Sixty healthy participants aged 60 to 75 years were randomly assigned to one of four music conditions: classical, jazz, pop, or silence. They completed a battery of cognitive tests measuring attention, memory, and executive functions, as well as a self-report questionnaire assessing their mood and music preferences. The results showed that classical music enhanced both memory and mood, compared to silence. Jazz music improved memory, but not mood, while pop music had no effect on either cognitive performance or mood. Music preferences did not influence the outcomes, except for a negative correlation between liking jazz and memory scores. These findings suggest that listening to classical music may be a simple and effective way to enhance the cognitive functioning and well-being of older adults.
output: - The influence of music genre on cognitive functioning and well-being of older adults: A randomized controlled trial

input: The development of novel anticancer agents is a major challenge in drug discovery. Among the various classes of natural products, terpenoids have been recognized as a rich source of bioactive compounds with diverse structures and biological activities. In this review, we focus on the recent advances in the discovery and development of terpenoids as anticancer agents, with an emphasis on the molecular mechanisms of action, the structure-activity relationships, and the synthetic strategies. We also discuss the challenges and perspectives of terpenoid-based anticancer drug development. We cover four major classes of terpenoids: monoterpenoids, sesquiterpenoids, diterpenoids, and triterpenoids, and provide examples of representative compounds that have shown promising anticancer activity in vitro and in vivo. Terpenoids have been shown to modulate various molecular targets and signaling pathways involved in cancer initiation, progression, and metastasis, such as apoptosis, cell cycle, angiogenesis, invasion, and inflammation. Some terpenoids have entered clinical trials or have been approved as anticancer drugs, such as taxanes, ingenols, and tanshinones. Synthetic approaches, including semisynthesis, total synthesis, and biosynthesis, have been developed to improve the availability, diversity, and potency of terpenoid derivatives. However, there are still many challenges to overcome, such as the low bioavailability, poor solubility, and unfavorable pharmacokinetics of some terpenoids, as well as the lack of selectivity and specificity for cancer cells. Further studies are needed to optimize the chemical and pharmacological properties of terpenoids, to identify novel targets and mechanisms, and to translate the preclinical findings into clinical applications.
output: - Terpenoids in cancer pharmacology: sources, modes of action, and development approaches

input: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance and mood of healthy older adults. Sixty participants aged 60 to 75 years were randomly assigned to one of four conditions: classical music, rock music, white noise, or silence. They completed a battery of cognitive tests measuring attention, memory, and executive functions, as well as a mood questionnaire, before and after listening to the assigned auditory stimulus for 15 minutes. The results showed that classical music improved attention and memory, but not executive functions, compared to the other conditions. Rock music and white noise impaired attention and memory, but not executive functions, compared to silence. Mood was not affected by the type of music, but by the individual preferences of the participants. These findings suggest that music can have both beneficial and detrimental effects on cognitive performance in older adults, depending on the music genre and the cognitive domain.
output: - Differential effects of music on cognitive performance in older adults: a study of attention, memory, and executive functions

input: We present a novel approach to automatically generate captions for images that contain human faces. Our approach leverages the rich information available in face analysis, such as facial expression, head pose, gender, age, and gaze direction, to produce descriptive and natural captions. We use a two-stage neural network model that first generates a face embedding vector from the face analysis results, and then feeds it into a recurrent neural network with an attention mechanism to generate the caption. We evaluate our approach on a large-scale face image captioning dataset, and show that it outperforms several baseline methods in terms of caption quality and diversity. We also conduct a human evaluation study to assess the readability and informativeness of the generated captions.
output: - A Novel Approach to Image Captioning using Face Analysis and Attention Mechanism

input: The human gut microbiota is a complex and dynamic community of microorganisms that plays a key role in health and disease. The composition and function of the gut microbiota are influenced by multiple factors, including diet, genetics, environment, and host immunity. However, the mechanisms by which these factors shape the gut microbiota and modulate its interactions with the host are not fully understood. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the factors that affect the gut microbiota and its impact on various aspects of human health, such as metabolism, immunity, inflammation, and infection. We also discuss the potential applications of gut microbiota manipulation, such as probiotics, prebiotics, fecal microbiota transplantation, and dietary interventions, for the prevention and treatment of various diseases. Finally, we highlight the challenges and limitations of gut microbiota research and suggest future directions for this emerging field.
output: - The impact of the gut microbiota on human metabolism, immunity, inflammation, and infection

input: The human gut microbiota is a complex ecosystem that plays a key role in health and disease. The composition and function of the gut microbiota are influenced by various factors, such as diet, genetics, environment, and host immunity. However, the mechanisms by which the gut microbiota interacts with the host and modulates its physiology and metabolism are not fully understood. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the metabolic interactions between the gut microbiota and the host, focusing on the production and utilization of short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs), bile acids, and vitamins. We also discuss the potential applications of gut microbiota modulation, such as fecal microbiota transplantation, probiotics, and prebiotics, for the prevention and treatment of metabolic disorders, such as obesity, diabetes, and cardiovascular diseases.
output: - The gut microbiota and host metabolism: a review of metabolic pathways and modulation strategies

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance and mood of older adults. Sixty healthy participants aged 60-75 years were randomly assigned to one of four music conditions: classical, jazz, pop, or no music. They completed a battery of cognitive tests measuring attention, memory, and executive functions, and a mood questionnaire before and after listening to music or silence for 15 minutes. The results showed that listening to classical music improved spatial working memory and verbal fluency, while listening to jazz music enhanced verbal memory and delayed recall. Listening to pop music or no music did not have any significant effects on cognition or mood. The mood questionnaire revealed that all types of music increased positive affect and decreased negative affect, but classical music had the strongest effect. These findings suggest that listening to music can modulate cognitive performance and mood in older adults, and that the effects may depend on the musical genre.
output: - Cognitive and mood benefits of listening to music in older adults: The role of musical genre

input: The development of effective vaccines against SARS-CoV-2, the causative agent of COVID-19, is a global public health priority. Several vaccine candidates are currently undergoing clinical trials, but the correlates of protection and the durability of immune responses are still unclear. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the immunology of SARS-CoV-2 infection and the challenges and opportunities for vaccine design. We discuss the features and limitations of different vaccine platforms, the selection and evaluation of immunogens, the measurement and interpretation of immune markers, and the potential for immune enhancement or escape. We also highlight the need for international coordination and collaboration to ensure the equitable and ethical distribution of vaccines to combat the pandemic.
output: - Vaccine strategies for SARS-CoV-2: immunogens, markers, and potential pitfalls

input: The human gut microbiota is a complex ecosystem that plays an important role in health and disease. The composition and function of the gut microbiota are influenced by various factors, such as diet, genetics, environment, and host immunity. Dysbiosis of the gut microbiota has been associated with various diseases, such as inflammatory bowel disease, obesity, diabetes, and cancer. However, the causal relationships and underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Metagenomics is a powerful tool to study the gut microbiota, as it allows the analysis of the collective genomes of the microbial community. Metagenomics can reveal the diversity, structure, and function of the gut microbiota, as well as the interactions between microbes and the host. However, metagenomics also faces many challenges, such as the complexity and heterogeneity of the gut microbiota, the limitations of bioinformatics tools, and the ethical and legal issues. In this review, we summarize the current state of the art of metagenomics applied to the gut microbiota, and discuss the opportunities and challenges for future research. We also provide some practical guidelines and recommendations for metagenomic studies of the gut microbiota.
output: - Metagenomic insights into the gut microbiota: from composition and function to disease and intervention

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on cognitive performance and mood in healthy older adults. Sixty participants completed a battery of neuropsychological tests and mood scales under three conditions: silence, classical music, and pop music. The results showed that classical music enhanced performance on tasks of verbal memory and visuospatial abilities, while pop music impaired performance on these tasks. Both types of music improved mood compared to silence, but classical music had a more positive effect than pop music. The findings suggest that music can modulate cognitive functioning and mood in older adults, depending on the characteristics of the music. The possible mechanisms underlying these effects are discussed.
output: - Cognitive and mood effects of silence, classical music, and pop music in older adults

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on cognitive performance and mood in healthy older adults. Sixty participants (mean age = 69.4 years) completed a battery of neuropsychological tests and mood scales under three conditions: silence, classical music, and rock music. The music conditions were counterbalanced and the tests were presented in a fixed order. The results showed that classical music enhanced verbal memory and mood, while rock music impaired memory performance and mood. There were no significant effects of music on attention, executive functions, or processing speed. The findings suggest that music can have both beneficial and detrimental effects on cognitive performance and mood in older adults, depending on the type of music and the cognitive domain. (Music and Cognition in Older Adults: The Influence of Music Type on Cognitive Performance and Mood)
output: - Cognitive and Mood Effects of Silence, Classical Music, and Rock Music in Older Adults

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance and mood of healthy older adults. Sixty participants (aged 60-75 years) were randomly assigned to one of four conditions: classical music, jazz music, pop music, or silence. They performed a battery of cognitive tasks, including memory, attention, and executive function tests, and completed a mood questionnaire before and after the music or silence exposure. The results showed that classical music enhanced memory and mood, compared to silence, while jazz music improved memory, but not mood, compared to silence. Pop music did not affect either memory or mood, compared to silence. There were no significant effects of music on attention or executive function. These findings suggest that music can have selective and beneficial effects on the cognitive performance and mood of older adults, depending on the genre and the task.
output: - Music genre, memory, and mood in older adults: A cognitive and affective study

input: The development of novel anticancer agents is a major challenge in drug discovery. Among the various classes of compounds, natural products and their derivatives have been recognized as a rich source of anticancer agents with diverse chemical structures and biological activities. In particular, terpenoids, which are the largest and most structurally diverse group of natural products, have shown promising anticancer effects against various types of cancer cells. Terpenoids can modulate multiple signaling pathways and molecular targets involved in cancer initiation, progression, and metastasis. Some terpenoids have been developed into clinically approved anticancer drugs, such as taxanes and camptothecins. However, the clinical application of many other terpenoids is limited by their low bioavailability, poor solubility, or severe side effects. Therefore, various strategies have been employed to overcome these limitations, such as structural modification, formulation development, combination therapy, and nanotechnology. This review summarizes the anticancer potential and molecular mechanisms of terpenoids and their derivatives, and discusses the current challenges and possible solutions for the development of terpenoid-based anticancer agents.
output: - Natural products for cancer therapy: terpenoids and their derivatives

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance and mood of older adults. Sixty healthy participants aged 60 to 83 years were randomly assigned to one of four music conditions: classical, jazz, pop, or silence. They completed a battery of cognitive tests measuring attention, memory, and executive functions, as well as a mood questionnaire, before and after listening to music or sitting in silence for 15 minutes. The results showed that listening to classical music improved spatial working memory and verbal fluency, while listening to jazz music enhanced verbal memory and mental flexibility. Listening to pop music or sitting in silence did not produce any significant changes in cognition or mood. The music conditions also influenced mood, with classical and jazz music increasing positive affect and arousal, and pop music decreasing negative affect. The findings suggest that listening to different types of music can have differential effects on the cognitive abilities and mood of older adults, and that music can be used as a cognitive enhancer or a mood regulator in this population.
output: - Music as a cognitive and mood enhancer in older adults: The role of music genre

input: The development of effective vaccines against SARS-CoV-2, the causative agent of COVID-19, is a global priority. Several vaccine candidates are currently in clinical trials, but the immunological correlates of protection and the durability of the immune response are still unclear. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the humoral and cellular immunity elicited by natural SARS-CoV-2 infection and by different vaccine platforms, such as mRNA, viral vectors, protein subunits and inactivated viruses. We also discuss the potential challenges for vaccine development, such as viral mutations, antibody-dependent enhancement and pre-existing immunity to vaccine components. Finally, we highlight the importance of animal models and the need for standardized assays to compare the immunogenicity and efficacy of different vaccine candidates.
output: - SARS-CoV-2 vaccines: current status, immunological correlates and future prospects

input: The gut microbiota is a complex ecosystem that influences host physiology and metabolism, immune function, and behavior. Alterations in the gut microbiota have been associated with various diseases, such as obesity, diabetes, inflammatory bowel disease, and neuropsychiatric disorders. However, the mechanisms by which the gut microbiota modulates host health and disease are not fully understood. One potential mediator of the gut-brain axis is the vagus nerve, a bidirectional neural pathway that connects the brain and the gastrointestinal tract. The vagus nerve is involved in the regulation of appetite, mood, stress, and inflammation, and can be modulated by electrical stimulation or pharmacological agents. Here, we review the evidence for the role of the vagus nerve in mediating the effects of the gut microbiota on host physiology and behavior, focusing on animal and human studies that have investigated the impact of microbiota manipulation, vagus nerve stimulation, or vagotomy on various outcomes. We also discuss the possible mechanisms by which the gut microbiota and the vagus nerve interact, such as the production of microbial metabolites, the activation of gut hormones and immune cells, and the modulation of the enteric nervous system. We propose that the gut microbiota and the vagus nerve form a dynamic and reciprocal loop that shapes host homeostasis and plasticity.
output: - The role of the vagus nerve in mediating the effects of the gut microbiota on host homeostasis and plasticity

input: Introduction: The rapid development of nanotechnology has led to the emergence of various nanomaterials with diverse applications, such as drug delivery, biosensing, imaging, and catalysis. However, the potential toxicity and environmental impact of nanomaterials have raised serious concerns about their safety and biocompatibility. Therefore, it is essential to evaluate the biological effects and interactions of nanomaterials with living systems. Among the various biological systems, the blood-brain barrier (BBB) is a critical interface that regulates the exchange of substances between the blood and the central nervous system (CNS). The BBB is composed of specialized endothelial cells, astrocytes, pericytes, and neurons, and it protects the CNS from harmful substances and maintains its homeostasis. However, the BBB also limits the delivery of therapeutic agents to the CNS, posing a major challenge for the treatment of neurological disorders. Nanomaterials have been explored as promising tools to modulate or overcome the BBB, either by enhancing their permeability across the BBB or by targeting specific receptors or transporters on the BBB. However, the interaction of nanomaterials with the BBB may also induce adverse effects, such as inflammation, oxidative stress, and disruption of the tight junctions. Therefore, it is important to understand the mechanisms and consequences of the nanomaterial-BBB interaction, as well as to develop reliable and relevant models to assess the BBB permeability and toxicity of nanomaterials. In this review, we summarize the recent advances and challenges in the field of nanomaterial-BBB interaction, focusing on the following aspects: (1) the structure and function of the BBB and its role in CNS diseases; (2) the strategies and mechanisms of nanomaterial-mediated modulation of the BBB; (3) the methods and models for evaluating the BBB permeability and toxicity of nanomaterials; and (4) the future perspectives and directions for the development of safe and effective nanomaterials for BBB modulation and CNS delivery.
output: - Nanomaterials for CNS delivery: how to modulate and assess the blood-brain barrier

input: The human gut microbiota is a complex and dynamic community of microorganisms that plays a vital role in health and disease. The composition and function of the gut microbiota are influenced by multiple factors, including diet, genetics, environment, and host immunity. Alterations in the gut microbiota, termed dysbiosis, have been associated with various gastrointestinal disorders, such as inflammatory bowel disease, irritable bowel syndrome, and colorectal cancer. However, the causal relationships between dysbiosis and disease remain unclear, and the mechanisms by which the gut microbiota modulates host physiology are not fully elucidated. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the structure and diversity of the human gut microbiota, the factors that shape its development and maintenance, and its interactions with the host immune system and the gut-brain axis. We also discuss the potential applications of gut microbiota manipulation, such as fecal microbiota transplantation, probiotics, and prebiotics, for the prevention and treatment of gastrointestinal diseases.
output: - Interactions and interventions of the human gut microbiota: a comprehensive overview of gastrointestinal disorders

input: This paper presents a novel approach to automatically generate captions for images based on deep neural networks. We propose a model that consists of two components: a convolutional neural network (CNN) that extracts visual features from the image, and a recurrent neural network (RNN) that generates a natural language description of the image. The RNN is trained with a novel objective function that maximizes the likelihood of the correct caption given the image features, while minimizing the exposure bias and the label bias. We also introduce a new dataset of images and captions, called Flickr8k-CN, which is a Chinese version of the Flickr8k dataset. We evaluate our model on both the Flickr8k-CN and the MSCOCO datasets, and show that it outperforms the state-of-the-art methods on both datasets in terms of BLEU, METEOR, ROUGE and CIDEr scores. We also conduct a human evaluation to compare the quality and diversity of the captions generated by our model and the existing methods.
output: - Improving Image Captioning Performance using a CNN-RNN Model and a New Chinese Dataset

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance of older adults. Sixty healthy older adults (mean age = 68.4 years) were randomly assigned to one of four groups: classical music, jazz music, pop music, or no music. They performed a battery of cognitive tasks, including memory, attention, executive function, and language tests, while listening to their assigned type of music or in silence. The results showed that classical music enhanced memory and attention, while jazz music improved executive function and language skills. Pop music had no significant effect on any cognitive domain. The findings suggest that music can have differential effects on the cognitive abilities of older adults, depending on the genre and the task. Implications for the use of music as a cognitive enhancer and the role of individual preferences are discussed.
output: - Differential effects of classical, jazz, and pop music on cognitive tasks in older adults

input: The human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) is the causative agent of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), a global pandemic that affects millions of people. HIV-1 infects and destroys CD4+ T cells, leading to progressive immunosuppression and opportunistic infections. The viral envelope glycoprotein gp120 is responsible for binding to the CD4 receptor and the chemokine coreceptor, either CCR5 or CXCR4, on the target cell surface. This interaction triggers a conformational change in the envelope glycoprotein gp41, which mediates the fusion of the viral and cellular membranes. The gp120-CD4-coreceptor interaction is a major target for antiviral drugs and neutralizing antibodies. However, HIV-1 exhibits a high degree of genetic diversity and immune evasion, which pose challenges for the development of effective therapies and vaccines. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the structure, function, and evolution of the HIV-1 envelope glycoprotein, with a focus on its interaction with the host cell receptors and the implications for viral entry and inhibition.
output: - Structural and functional insights into the HIV-1 envelope glycoprotein and its role in viral infection

input: Background: The gut microbiota plays a crucial role in human health and disease, but the factors that shape its composition and function are not fully understood. Diet is one of the main drivers of microbiota variation, but the effects of different dietary patterns on the gut microbiota and its metabolic output are still poorly characterized. Objective: We aimed to compare the effects of two dietary patterns, a Western diet (WD) and a Mediterranean diet (MD), on the gut microbiota and fecal metabolome of healthy adults. Methods: We conducted a randomized crossover trial with 20 healthy volunteers who consumed a WD and a MD for 4 weeks each, separated by a 2-week washout period. Fecal samples were collected at baseline and at the end of each intervention period and analyzed by 16S rRNA gene sequencing and untargeted metabolomics. Results: Both diets induced significant changes in the gut microbiota composition and function, but the direction and magnitude of these changes differed between the diets. The WD increased the relative abundance of Bacteroides and Bilophila, genera associated with animal protein and fat digestion, and decreased the relative abundance of Prevotella and Roseburia, genera involved in the fermentation of dietary fiber. The WD also increased the fecal levels of bile acids, branched-chain amino acids, and phenolic compounds, and decreased the levels of short-chain fatty acids and indole derivatives. The MD had opposite effects on most of these microbial groups and metabolites, suggesting a different impact on gut health. Conclusions: Our findings demonstrate that the WD and the MD have distinct and rapid effects on the gut microbiota and its metabolic output, which may have implications for disease prevention and treatment.
output: - Western and Mediterranean diets modulate the gut microbiota and fecal metabolites differently in healthy individuals

input: The development of artificial intelligence (AI) has brought significant benefits to various fields of human endeavor, but also raised ethical, social, and legal challenges. One of the most pressing issues is how to ensure that AI systems are aligned with human values and respect human dignity, autonomy, and rights. This paper reviews the main ethical principles and frameworks that have been proposed for AI, and discusses some of the challenges and limitations of applying them in practice. It also examines the role of law and regulation in governing AI, and the potential of using AI to enhance legal decision-making and access to justice. The paper concludes with some suggestions for future research directions and policy implications.
output: - Ethical and Legal Dimensions of Artificial Intelligence: A Critical Overview and Future Directions

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance and mood of older adults. Sixty participants aged 60 to 75 years were randomly assigned to one of four conditions: classical music, jazz music, pop music, or silence. They completed a battery of cognitive tests measuring attention, memory, and executive functions, as well as a mood questionnaire, before and after listening to music or silence for 15 minutes. The results showed that classical music improved attention and memory, but not executive functions, compared to silence. Jazz music enhanced mood, but not cognitive performance, compared to silence. Pop music had no significant effects on either cognition or mood. The findings suggest that music can have selective and beneficial effects on the cognitive functioning and emotional state of older adults, depending on the genre and the task.
output: - The cognitive and mood effects of listening to music in older adults: Classical music enhances attention and memory, jazz music improves mood

input: The human gut microbiota is a complex and dynamic ecosystem that plays a key role in health and disease. The composition and function of the gut microbiota are influenced by multiple factors, including diet, host genetics, environmental exposures, and medications. Among these, antibiotics are known to have profound and lasting effects on the gut microbiota, altering its diversity, structure, and metabolic potential. However, the mechanisms by which antibiotics affect the gut microbiota and the consequences for host health are not fully understood. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the impact of antibiotics on the gut microbiota, focusing on the effects of different classes, doses, and durations of antibiotic treatment. We also discuss the potential implications of antibiotic-induced dysbiosis for various diseases, such as inflammatory bowel disease, obesity, diabetes, and infections. Finally, we highlight the challenges and opportunities for future research in this field, as well as the potential strategies to restore or maintain a healthy gut microbiota after antibiotic exposure.
output: - Antibiotics and the human gut microbiota: a review of current knowledge and future directions

input: The human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) is the causative agent of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), a global pandemic that has claimed millions of lives. HIV-1 infects and destroys CD4+ T cells, the key players of the adaptive immune system, leading to progressive immunosuppression and opportunistic infections. The viral envelope glycoprotein gp120 is responsible for binding to the CD4 receptor and the chemokine coreceptor, either CCR5 or CXCR4, on the surface of the target cell. This interaction triggers a conformational change in the envelope glycoprotein gp41, which mediates the fusion of the viral and cellular membranes. The envelope glycoproteins are the main targets of the humoral immune response, but they are also highly variable and shielded by glycosylation, making the development of an effective vaccine a major challenge. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the structure, function, and diversity of the HIV-1 envelope glycoproteins, and discuss the strategies and obstacles for eliciting neutralizing antibodies against this important viral antigen.
output: - Neutralizing antibody responses to HIV-1 envelope glycoproteins: molecular mechanisms and vaccine design

input: The development of artificial neural networks (ANNs) has enabled various applications in different domains, such as computer vision, natural language processing, and robotics. However, the design and optimization of ANNs often require extensive human expertise and computational resources, which limit their accessibility and scalability. To address this challenge, automated machine learning (AutoML) techniques have been proposed to automate the process of ANN architecture search, hyperparameter tuning, and model compression. In this survey, we provide a comprehensive and systematic review of the recent advances and challenges in AutoML for ANNs. We first introduce the basic concepts and components of AutoML, and then present a taxonomy of AutoML methods based on their search strategies, evaluation methods, and optimization objectives. We also discuss the applications and benchmarks of AutoML in various domains, and highlight the future directions and open issues in this emerging field.
output: - A Taxonomy and Review of AutoML Methods for ANNs

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance of older adults. Sixty healthy participants aged 60 to 75 years were randomly assigned to one of four music conditions: classical, jazz, pop, or no music. They performed a battery of cognitive tests, including memory, attention, executive function, and processing speed tasks. The results showed that classical music enhanced memory and attention, while jazz music improved executive function and processing speed. Pop music had no significant effect on any cognitive domain. The findings suggest that music can have differential effects on cognitive functions depending on the genre and the task.
output: - Music genre and cognitive enhancement in older adults: a study of memory, attention, executive function, and processing speed tasks

input: In this paper, we propose a novel approach to generate natural language summaries from multiple documents on the same topic. Our approach consists of three main steps: document clustering, sentence extraction, and summary generation. First, we cluster the input documents into subtopics using a graph-based method that exploits lexical and semantic similarities. Second, we extract salient sentences from each subtopic cluster using a neural network model that considers both intra-cluster and inter-cluster information. Third, we generate a summary from the extracted sentences using a transformer-based model that incorporates document and subtopic information. We evaluate our approach on two multi-document summarization datasets, DUC-2004 and Multi-News, and show that it outperforms several strong baselines in terms of ROUGE scores and human judgments. We also conduct ablation studies and qualitative analysis to demonstrate the effectiveness of each component of our approach.
output: - Leveraging Lexical and Semantic Similarities for Subtopic Clustering and Neural Multi-Document Summarization

input: The development of effective vaccines against COVID-19 is a global priority, but the emergence of new variants of SARS-CoV-2 poses a challenge for vaccine design and evaluation. Here, we report the immunogenicity and efficacy of a single-dose adenovirus-vectored vaccine, ChAdOx1 nCoV-19 (AZD1222), against the B.1.351 variant of concern in South Africa. We conducted a multicentre, double-blind, randomised, placebo-controlled phase 1/2 trial in HIV-negative adults aged 18-64 years, who received either ChAdOx1 nCoV-19 (5x10^10 viral particles) or placebo by intramuscular injection. The primary outcome was the safety and reactogenicity of the vaccine. The secondary outcomes included the humoral and cellular immune responses to the vaccine and the vaccine efficacy against symptomatic COVID-19 caused by the B.1.351 variant. Results: Between June 24 and November 9, 2020, we enrolled 2026 participants, of whom 1010 received ChAdOx1 nCoV-19 and 1011 received placebo. The median follow-up time was 121 days. The vaccine had a good safety profile and was well tolerated, with similar reactogenicity to previous trials. The vaccine induced robust humoral and cellular immune responses, with higher neutralising antibody titres against the B.1.351 variant than against the original strain (D614G). However, the vaccine efficacy against the B.1.351 variant was only 10.4% (95% CI -76.8 to 54.8), compared to 75.8% (95% CI 33.0 to 91.9) against the original strain. The vaccine efficacy against severe COVID-19 was not assessed due to the low number of cases. Conclusions: ChAdOx1 nCoV-19 showed reduced efficacy against mild to moderate COVID-19 caused by the B.1.351 variant in South Africa, despite inducing cross-reactive immune responses. These findings highlight the need for a new generation of vaccines that can protect against emerging variants of SARS-CoV-2.
output: - A phase 1/2 trial of ChAdOx1 nCoV-19 vaccine in South Africa: safety, immunogenicity and efficacy against the B.1.351 variant

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance of older adults. Sixty healthy participants aged 60-75 years were randomly assigned to one of four groups: classical music, rock music, white noise or silence. They performed a battery of cognitive tests, including memory, attention, executive function and mood, before and after listening to their assigned auditory stimulus for 15 minutes. The results showed that classical music improved memory and mood, rock music impaired memory and attention, white noise had no effect and silence worsened mood. The findings suggest that music can modulate cognitive functions in older adults, depending on the type and characteristics of the music.
output: - Classical music enhances memory and mood, rock music impairs them: A cognitive test battery in older adults

input: The human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) is the causative agent of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), a global pandemic that has claimed millions of lives. The virus infects and destroys CD4+ T cells, the key orchestrators of the adaptive immune system, leading to progressive immunosuppression and opportunistic infections. The viral envelope glycoprotein (Env) is the sole target of neutralizing antibodies and the main determinant of viral entry. Env is a trimeric complex composed of three gp120 subunits, which bind to the CD4 receptor and a coreceptor (usually CCR5 or CXCR4), and three gp41 subunits, which mediate membrane fusion. Env is highly variable and undergoes extensive glycosylation, which shield it from antibody recognition. Despite these challenges, some HIV-1-infected individuals develop broadly neutralizing antibodies (bNAbs) that can recognize diverse viral strains and prevent infection in animal models. These bNAbs are valuable tools for vaccine design and therapy, but their elicitation by immunization remains a major unsolved problem. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the structure and function of HIV-1 Env, the molecular mechanisms of viral entry, the characteristics and targets of bNAbs, and the strategies to induce them by vaccination.
output: - Neutralizing the diversity of HIV-1: the envelope glycoprotein and its epitopes for broadly neutralizing antibodies

input: In this paper, we propose a novel approach to automatically generate captions for images that contain human activities. We use a deep neural network that consists of three components: a convolutional neural network (CNN) to extract visual features from the image, a long short-term memory (LSTM) network to encode the temporal dynamics of the activities, and an attention mechanism to selectively focus on the most relevant parts of the image and the activity sequence. We train our model on a large-scale dataset of images and videos with human-annotated captions, and evaluate it on two benchmark datasets: the MPII Human Pose dataset and the Stanford 40 Actions dataset. We show that our model outperforms the state-of-the-art methods on both datasets in terms of caption quality and activity recognition accuracy. We also demonstrate that our model can generate diverse and descriptive captions that capture the details and nuances of human activities.
output: - Capturing human activities in images with an attentive neural network

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance of older adults. Previous research has suggested that music can enhance various aspects of cognition, such as attention, memory, and executive functions, but the results are inconsistent and depend on several factors, such as the individual's musical preference, the type and complexity of the task, and the musical features of the stimuli. In this study, we compared the effects of four types of music: classical, jazz, rock, and pop, on three cognitive tasks: digit span, Stroop, and trail making. We also measured the participants' subjective mood and arousal levels before and after the tasks. We hypothesized that classical music would have the most beneficial effect on cognition, followed by jazz, rock, and pop, and that this effect would be mediated by mood and arousal. We recruited 40 healthy older adults (aged 60-80 years) and randomly assigned them to one of the four music groups. Each participant listened to 15 minutes of music and then performed the three cognitive tasks in a counterbalanced order. The results showed that classical music significantly improved the performance on the digit span and Stroop tasks, compared to the other types of music, but had no effect on the trail making task. Jazz music also improved the performance on the digit span task, but not on the other two tasks. Rock and pop music had no significant effects on any of the tasks. The mood and arousal levels of the participants did not differ significantly across the music groups, and did not mediate the effects of music on cognition. These findings suggest that classical and jazz music can enhance some aspects of cognitive performance in older adults, but the mechanisms underlying this effect remain unclear.
output: - Cognitive benefits of classical and jazz music in older adults: A contrast with rock and pop music on three cognitive tasks

input: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of different types of music on the stress levels and immune responses of patients undergoing coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery. A randomized controlled trial was conducted with 60 patients who were assigned to one of three groups: relaxing music, preferred music, or control (no music). Music was delivered via headphones for 30 minutes on the day before and the day after the surgery. Stress levels were measured by salivary cortisol and anxiety scores, and immune responses were assessed by serum interleukin-6 (IL-6) and immunoglobulin A (IgA). The results showed that both music groups had significantly lower cortisol and anxiety levels than the control group at both time points. The music groups also had significantly lower IL-6 levels and higher IgA levels than the control group after the surgery. The relaxing music group had the lowest cortisol and IL-6 levels and the highest IgA levels among the three groups. These findings suggest that music can reduce stress and enhance immune function in CABG patients, and that relaxing music may have more beneficial effects than preferred music.
output: - Relaxing music versus preferred music for stress and immune modulation in coronary artery bypass graft surgery: A randomized controlled trial

input: The human gut microbiota is a complex and dynamic ecosystem that plays a crucial role in health and disease. Alterations in the gut microbiota composition and function have been associated with various chronic diseases, such as obesity, diabetes, inflammatory bowel disease, and cancer. However, the mechanisms by which the gut microbiota influences host physiology and pathology are not fully understood. Metabolomics is a powerful tool to study the metabolic interactions between the gut microbiota and the host, as it can capture the global biochemical changes in biological samples. Metabolomics can be applied to different types of samples, such as feces, blood, urine, and tissue, to provide a comprehensive picture of the host-microbiota co-metabolism. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the role of the gut microbiota in human health and disease, with a focus on the metabolomic approaches used to investigate the gut microbiota-host metabolic crosstalk. We also discuss the challenges and perspectives of metabolomics in microbiome research.
output: - Metabolomic insights into the gut microbiota and host physiology and pathology

input: This paper investigates the effects of different types of feedback on the learning outcomes of students in a flipped classroom setting. Flipped classroom is an instructional approach that reverses the traditional order of delivering lectures and assigning homework, by providing online video lectures before class and engaging students in active learning activities during class. Feedback is an essential component of flipped classroom, as it helps students monitor their progress and adjust their learning strategies. However, not all feedback is equally effective, and different feedback types may have different impacts on students' motivation, self-regulation, and achievement. In this paper, the authors compare four types of feedback: no feedback, knowledge of results, elaborated feedback, and peer feedback. They conduct a quasi-experimental study with 120 undergraduate students enrolled in a statistics course, who are randomly assigned to one of the four feedback conditions. The authors measure the students' pretest and posttest scores, as well as their self-reported levels of motivation, self-regulation, and satisfaction. The results show that elaborated feedback and peer feedback lead to significantly higher learning gains than no feedback and knowledge of results. Moreover, elaborated feedback and peer feedback also enhance students' motivation, self-regulation, and satisfaction, while no feedback and knowledge of results have negative effects on these variables. The authors discuss the implications of these findings for flipped classroom design and suggest directions for future research.
output: - Feedback Matters: A Study of Four Feedback Conditions in Flipped Classroom

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance and mood of older adults. Sixty healthy participants (aged 60-75 years) were randomly assigned to one of four music conditions: classical, jazz, pop, or silence. They completed a battery of cognitive tests measuring attention, memory, and executive functions, as well as a mood questionnaire, before and after listening to music for 15 minutes. The results showed that classical music improved spatial working memory and abstract reasoning, jazz music enhanced verbal memory, and pop music increased processing speed. Music also improved mood and reduced negative emotions. Silence had no significant effects on cognition or mood. These findings suggest that music can be used as a cognitive enhancer and a mood regulator for older adults, depending on the type of music and the cognitive domain.
output: - Different music genres, different cognitive outcomes: A study of music effects on attention, memory, and executive functions in older adults

input: In this paper, we propose a novel approach to generate natural language summaries of complex data tables. Our approach consists of three main steps: table preprocessing, summary generation, and summary postprocessing. In the table preprocessing step, we extract relevant information from the table, such as the table title, column headers, row labels, and cell values. We also identify the key attributes and measures of the table, and perform data analysis to derive insights from the table. In the summary generation step, we use a neural network model to generate a summary based on the extracted information and the derived insights. The neural network model is trained on a large corpus of data tables and their summaries, and learns to produce fluent and informative summaries. In the summary postprocessing step, we refine the generated summary by correcting grammatical errors, resolving anaphora, and adding discourse markers. We evaluate our approach on a benchmark dataset of data tables and their summaries, and show that it outperforms existing methods in terms of both automatic and human evaluation metrics.
output: - Summarizing Data Tables in Natural Language with Neural Networks and Data Preprocessing

input: We present a novel approach for generating natural language summaries of long scientific documents, such as research papers and patents. Our method is based on a two-stage process: first, we extract salient sentences from the document using a neural network model that learns to rank sentences based on their relevance and diversity. Second, we rewrite the extracted sentences into a coherent and concise summary using a neural text simplification model that adapts to the domain and style of the input document. We evaluate our method on a new dataset of research paper and patent summaries, and show that it outperforms existing extractive and abstractive baselines in terms of ROUGE scores and human judgments. We also demonstrate that our method can generate summaries of different lengths and granularities by varying the number of sentences to extract and rewrite.
output: - Summarizing Research Papers and Patents with Neural Sentence Extraction and Rewriting

input: We investigated the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance of healthy older adults. We randomly assigned 60 participants (aged 60-75) to one of three conditions: classical music, rock music, or silence. They completed a battery of cognitive tests, including memory, attention, and executive function tasks, while listening to the assigned music or no music. We found that classical music enhanced memory and attention, but not executive function, compared to silence. Rock music had no significant effect on any cognitive domain. We suggest that classical music may have a beneficial effect on cognitive functions that rely on temporal processing and arousal regulation.
output: - Memory and attention enhancement by classical music in older adults: A cognitive test battery approach

input: The development of artificial neural networks (ANNs) has enabled various applications in different domains, such as computer vision, natural language processing, and bioinformatics. However, the design and optimization of ANNs often require extensive human expertise and computational resources, which limit their scalability and accessibility. To address this challenge, neural architecture search (NAS) has emerged as a promising technique that can automatically discover optimal or near-optimal architectures for a given task and dataset. NAS methods can be broadly categorized into three types: reinforcement learning-based, evolutionary algorithm-based, and gradient-based. In this survey, we provide a comprehensive overview of the existing NAS methods, their advantages and disadvantages, and the common evaluation metrics and benchmarks. We also discuss the current challenges and future directions of NAS research.
output: - Neural Architecture Search: An Overview of the State-of-the-Art and Future Challenges

input: The human gut microbiota is a complex ecosystem that plays a key role in health and disease. The composition and function of the gut microbiota are influenced by various factors, such as diet, genetics, environment, and host immunity. However, the mechanisms by which these factors shape the gut microbiota and modulate its interactions with the host are not fully understood. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the factors that affect the gut microbiota and its impact on the host, focusing on the role of diet and dietary components. We discuss how diet can alter the gut microbiota composition, diversity, and function, as well as its interactions with the host immune system, metabolism, and behavior. We also highlight the potential of dietary interventions, such as probiotics, prebiotics, and synbiotics, to modulate the gut microbiota and improve host health. Finally, we identify the challenges and future directions for research on the gut microbiota and diet.
output: - Dietary modulation of the gut microbiota: composition, function, and host outcomes

input: In this paper, we propose a novel approach to automatically generate captions for images that contain human activities. We use a deep neural network that consists of three components: a convolutional neural network (CNN) to extract visual features from the image, a recurrent neural network (RNN) to encode the temporal dynamics of the human activities, and an attention mechanism to selectively attend to the most relevant parts of the image and the activity sequence. We train our model on a large-scale dataset of images and videos with human activity annotations, and evaluate it on two benchmark datasets for image captioning: Flickr30k Entities and MSCOCO. We show that our model outperforms the state-of-the-art methods on both datasets in terms of various automatic and human evaluation metrics. Moreover, we demonstrate that our model can generate captions that are not only accurate, but also diverse and informative, by incorporating the details and nuances of the human activities.
output: - Capturing the details and nuances of human activities in image captioning with a deep neural network and attention mechanism

input: In this paper, we propose a novel approach to generate natural language summaries from structured data, such as tables, graphs, or databases. Unlike existing methods that rely on template-based or sequence-to-sequence models, our approach leverages the semantic structure of the data and the natural language to produce coherent and informative summaries. We introduce a new neural network architecture that consists of three components: a data encoder, a language decoder, and a semantic aligner. The data encoder encodes the input data into a latent representation that captures its salient features. The language decoder generates a summary from the latent representation using a recurrent neural network with attention mechanism. The semantic aligner aligns the summary with the data and ensures that the summary is faithful and consistent with the data. We evaluate our approach on two benchmark datasets: WikiBio and WebNLG. We show that our approach outperforms the state-of-the-art methods in terms of both automatic and human evaluation metrics. We also conduct an ablation study to demonstrate the effectiveness of each component of our approach.
output: - Data Encoder, Language Decoder, and Semantic Aligner: A Novel Framework for Structured Data Summarization

input: In this paper, we propose a novel approach to generate natural language summaries from structured data, such as tables or knowledge graphs. Our approach leverages the power of pre-trained language models and adapts them to the task of data-to-text generation using a two-stage framework. In the first stage, we use a table-to-text model to generate a coarse summary from the input data, which captures the main information and facts. In the second stage, we use a text-to-text model to refine the coarse summary and make it more fluent, coherent, and informative. We evaluate our approach on two benchmark datasets, WikiBio and WebNLG, and show that it achieves state-of-the-art results in terms of both automatic and human evaluation metrics. We also conduct extensive ablation studies and analysis to demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of our approach.
output: - From Data to Fluent Text: A Two-Stage Data-to-Text Generation Approach with Pre-trained Language Models

input: The human gut microbiota plays a key role in health and disease, influencing diverse aspects of metabolism, immunity, and behavior. However, the molecular mechanisms by which the gut microbes interact with the host and with each other are still poorly understood. Here, we present a computational framework for the systematic discovery of metabolic interactions between bacterial species in the gut. We integrated genome-scale metabolic models of 773 human gut bacteria with a comprehensive database of dietary components and host metabolites, and used flux balance analysis to simulate the metabolic behavior of each species in isolation and in co-culture. We identified over 4,000 metabolic interactions between pairs of species, involving the exchange of metabolites such as amino acids, vitamins, and bile acids. We validated our approach by comparing our predictions with experimental data on the growth and metabolite production of selected bacterial pairs. We further applied our framework to explore the potential effects of diet and antibiotics on the metabolic interactions in the gut microbiota. Our results provide a global and mechanistic view of the metabolic interactions within the human gut microbiota, and offer a novel tool for studying its ecology and evolution.
output: - Metabolic interactions in the human gut microbiota: a genome-scale approach

input: This paper presents a novel approach to automatically generate captions for images based on deep neural networks. We propose a hybrid model that combines a convolutional neural network (CNN) for image feature extraction and a recurrent neural network (RNN) for natural language generation. The CNN encodes the input image into a fixed-length vector, which is then fed into the RNN to produce a sequence of words as the caption. We also introduce a new dataset of image-caption pairs, collected from Flickr, which is larger and more diverse than the existing datasets. We evaluate our model on both the new dataset and the popular MSCOCO dataset, and show that it outperforms the state-of-the-art methods in terms of BLEU and METEOR scores. Furthermore, we demonstrate that our model can generate captions for images that are not in the training set, and that it can handle complex scenes with multiple objects and actions. http://dx.
output: - Deep Neural Networks for Image Captioning: A Hybrid Model and a New Dataset from Flickr

input: The emergence of novel coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has posed a serious threat to global public health and economic stability. Rapid and accurate diagnosis of COVID-19 is crucial for timely intervention and containment of the pandemic. However, the current gold standard for COVID-19 diagnosis, reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR), has several limitations, such as high cost, long turnaround time, and susceptibility to false negatives. Therefore, there is an urgent need for alternative diagnostic methods that are simple, rapid, and reliable. In this review, we summarize the recent advances in the development of biosensors for COVID-19 detection, based on various sensing principles and platforms, such as electrochemical, optical, and nanomaterial-based biosensors. We also discuss the challenges and future perspectives of biosensor applications for COVID-19 diagnosis and monitoring.
output: Biosensors for COVID-19 detection: Current status and future prospects

input: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different types of music on the cognitive performance and mood of older adults. Sixty participants (aged 65 or above) were randomly assigned to one of four conditions: classical music, jazz music, pop music, or silence. They completed a battery of cognitive tests measuring memory, attention, and executive functions, as well as a mood questionnaire, before and after listening to music or sitting in silence for 15 minutes. The results showed that classical music improved memory and attention, while jazz music enhanced executive functions. Pop music and silence did not have any significant effects on cognition or mood. The mood questionnaire revealed that classical and jazz music also increased positive affect and reduced negative affect, while pop music and silence had no impact on mood. These findings suggest that music can be a potential cognitive and emotional enhancer for older adults, depending on the genre and the cognitive domain.
output: - The effects of music genre on cognitive performance and mood in older adults: A randomized controlled trial

input: The human gut microbiota is a complex and dynamic community of microorganisms that plays a crucial role in health and disease. The composition and function of the gut microbiota are influenced by multiple factors, including diet, genetics, environment, and host immunity. Dysbiosis of the gut microbiota, defined as an imbalance in the relative abundance or activity of beneficial and harmful microbes, has been associated with various chronic inflammatory and metabolic disorders, such as inflammatory bowel disease, obesity, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease. Modulating the gut microbiota through dietary interventions, probiotics, prebiotics, or fecal microbiota transplantation has emerged as a promising strategy to prevent or treat these diseases. However, the mechanisms by which the gut microbiota interacts with the host and influences the pathogenesis and progression of these diseases are not fully understood. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the role of the gut microbiota in health and disease, the factors that shape the gut microbiota, and the potential of microbiota-targeted therapies to improve human health.
output: - Diet, Immunity, and the Gut Microbiota: Implications for Health and Disease

input: This paper presents a novel approach to automatically generate captions for images based on deep neural networks. We propose a hybrid model that combines a convolutional neural network (CNN) for image feature extraction and a recurrent neural network (RNN) for natural language generation. The CNN encodes the input image into a fixed-length vector, which is then fed into the RNN to generate a caption word by word. The RNN is trained with a maximum likelihood objective using a large corpus of image-caption pairs. We also introduce a new evaluation metric, called BLEU-4, that measures the quality of the generated captions by comparing them with human-written references. We evaluate our model on two benchmark datasets, Flickr8k and Flickr30k, and show that it outperforms the state-of-the-art methods in terms of BLEU-4 score and human judgment.
output: - CNN-RNN Hybrid Model for Automatic Image Captioning and Evaluation

input: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of different types of music on the stress levels and cognitive performance of healthy young adults. Sixty participants were randomly assigned to one of four groups: classical music, heavy metal music, white noise, or silence. They completed a series of tasks that measured their memory, attention, and executive functions, as well as their salivary cortisol and alpha-amylase levels, before and after the intervention. The results showed that classical music significantly reduced stress levels and improved memory and executive functions, while heavy metal music increased stress levels and impaired memory and attention. White noise and silence had no significant effects on any of the variables. These findings suggest that music can modulate the physiological and psychological responses to stress and influence cognitive performance in a genre-specific manner.
output: - Classical music improves memory and executive functions while heavy metal music impairs them: a study on stress and cognition

input: The development of novel anticancer agents is an urgent need for improving the survival and quality of life of cancer patients. Among the various classes of natural products, flavonoids have attracted considerable attention as potential anticancer agents due to their wide distribution, low toxicity, and diverse biological activities. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the anticancer effects and mechanisms of action of flavonoids, focusing on their modulation of cell cycle, apoptosis, autophagy, epithelial-mesenchymal transition, angiogenesis, invasion, and metastasis. We also discuss the structure-activity relationship, bioavailability, and clinical relevance of flavonoids as anticancer agents. Furthermore, we highlight the challenges and perspectives for the future development of flavonoids as anticancer therapeutics. We hope that this review will provide a comprehensive overview of the anticancer potential and molecular targets of flavonoids and stimulate further research in this promising field.
output: - Flavonoids in cancer prevention and treatment: a critical appraisal

input: The development of effective vaccines against SARS-CoV-2, the causative agent of COVID-19, is a global priority. Several vaccine candidates are currently in clinical trials, but the immunological correlates of protection and the durability of immune responses are still unclear. In this review, we summarize the current knowledge on the humoral and cellular immune responses elicited by natural SARS-CoV-2 infection and by different vaccine platforms.
